Overview and Fantasy Impact of the QB Position 
The NFL has entered a new era with its approach to young quarterbacks. After 4-6 years of questioning whether recent 
developments have been an anomaly, the 2015-24 quarterback classes have done enough to tell us that the many NFL 
clubs have embraced the idea of fitting the scheme to the player rather than forcing the player to adapt to the scheme.  
 
Though the NFL has borrowed from the college and high school levels, professional football is not remotely close to having 
the offensive diversity of the college or high school game.  
 
There are still traditional West Coast offenses like Kyle Shanahan’s where fullbacks aren’t a mythological creature and tight 
ends that play in-line aren’t an endangered species.  
 
On the other end of the spectrum, the Baltimore Ravens often compress the field to create outside rushing lanes for the 
most dynamic runner at the quarterback position since Michael Vick. The Eagles used a lot of spread concepts and read 
option to ease Jalen Hurts into the league. Jayden Daniels, while known for his deep passing, operates in a Kliff Kingsbury 
offense that does a vast majority its work within the first five yards of the line of scrimmage.  
 
Analysts have accepted the trend towards quarterbacks who can move and threaten the defense with their rushing ability. 
Many are now declaring that the age of the classic pocket quarterback died with Tom Brady, Drew Brees, and Ben 
Roethlisberger leaving the game.  
 
Proclamations are exciting. They generate clicks, lead to arguments that generate more clicks, and now that you’re 
thoroughly frustrated with your descent into the cesspool of the comments section or your social media exchanges. 
Eventually, your brain has been appropriately tenderized to click the ad for the five best stock tips of 2023 or the sports 
handicapper posing as Nostradamus.  
 
Though the dopamine rush of the internet click machine is real, the NFL pocket isn’t goi

Though the dopamine rush of the internet click machine is real, the NFL pocket isn’t going anywhere. Quarterbacks who run 
must still win from the pocket in pivotal situations.  
 
Pocket play is a craft that passers can’t acquire quickly or simply, and the flaws in long-term quarterback development 
remain the same. A look at the recent quarterback classes reveals why this is the case.  
 
The network media gave weak marks to the 2016 class before the NFL Combine. Critics of the class believed that the 
valuation of Jared Goff and Carson Wentz was on equal terms with Jameis Winston and Marcus Mariota from 2015 was 
strictly an attention-seeking ploy to promote the entertainment value of the NFL Draft.  
 
The short-term and reactionary perspectives of media and fans panned Goff after a difficult rookie year. If you asked most 
analysts which of the four would have the best career 6-7 years later, Goff would have been the last choice. Now, he might 
be the best. Many thought the Lions would draft Goff’s eventual replacement last year, but Hendon Hooker is a 
developmental option, and Goff led the Lions within minutes of their first Super Bowl.  
 
Critics of the media believe the buzz about each new crop of players is an annual phenomenon of draft season analysis. 
Regardless of the reputation the current quarterback class earns before the NFL Combine, there’s a belief that national 
television media’s broadcast agreements with the league influences the amount of buzz given to the top 2-3 passers in the 
class.  
 
Critics see this as a healthy, pre-draft public relations boost because it benefits their employers when the NFL has dramatic 
story arcs. Like every good conspiracy theory, there’s a grain of truth within the claim. The national football media needs 
compelling stories and quarterback-driven narratives generate lots of interest.  
 
Three years

text:
ry good conspiracy theory, there’s a grain of truth within the claim. The national football media needs 
compelling stories and quarterback-driven narratives generate lots of interest.  
 
Three years ago, several of the Big Media sites saw draft coverage decline significantly from previous years. The rationale 
for the loss in attention? A lack of top quarterback talent.  
 
So, yes, there has been some truth to the idea that quarterback talent drives the perception of a draft’s value. And whether 
that value is real or largely projection, the NFL perpetuates the media narrative by continually selecting passers in the first 
round as much on the basis of projection and potential as on proven skill.  
 
During an ESPN NFL Draft special several years ago, Hall of Fame head coach Bill Parcells told the audience that if a team 
believes a prospect might have potential to develop into a franchise quarterback it must take that quarterback in the first 
round or miss its chance. It’s this attitude, the league’s draft habits, and the low success rate of quarterback development 
that reinforce the idea that teams are desperate for quarterbacks. 
 
As a result, the national media recognizes the self-fulfilling prophecy – and the value of gaining viewer eyeballs – that result 
from touting quarterbacks as potential first-round picks and making them the focal points of draft-season narratives.  
 
However, much to my personal delight, the NFL didn’t bite on the 2022 class – Kenny Pickett was the only quarterback 
selected before the third round and was not a top-15 pick.  

 
3 
 
The 2022 class still lends itself well to what I’ve been saying for a number of years. The idea that the annual rise in value of 
quarterback classes is primarily a media ploy doesn’t account for the most realistic explanation: The draft media doesn’t 
know enough about the draft classes when they are required to talk about them.  
 
The demand for analysis on next year’s quarterback class begins imm
analysis: This text discusses the media's role in inflating the perceived value of quarterback prospects in the NFL Draft, not individual quarterbacks.  It argues that the media's focus on quarterbacks, driven by the need for compelling narratives and viewer interest, creates a self-fulfilling prophecy where teams prioritize quarterbacks highly, even if their talent is largely projected rather than proven.  The 2022 draft is cited as an exception, where only one quarterback was selected before the third round, contradicting the usual hype.  The text doesn't offer individual quarterback analyses or comparisons.

t realistic explanation: The draft media doesn’t 
know enough about the draft classes when they are required to talk about them.  
 
The demand for analysis on next year’s quarterback class begins immediately after the current draft ends. To fulfill this 
unrealistic demand, incomplete assessments of talent saturate television, radio, and internet throughout the spring, 
summer, and fall.  
 
When analysts finally develop a complete picture of the class, there’s already been 8-9 months of reactive talking points 
that look shallow and ill-informed when compared to the refined thoughts shared in February and March. The public has 
difficulty shaking the early misguided perspectives. 
 
Returning to the 2016 class, it’s why fans and draft analysts suggested NFL agents were manipulating the media into 
artificially raising the perception of the group. Although Goff, Wentz, and Dak Prescott had their ups and downs, Goff led his 
team to a Super Bowl and Prescott had one of his best seasons in 2023.  
 
Interestingly enough, all three earned public praise as young franchise quarterbacks during their first two seasons. The buzz 
came too early because it takes about 30 games to get an accurate idea of the quarterback’s acclimation to the NFL. 
Inevitably, opposing defenses developed a book on these young quarterbacks and we gradually saw these signal callers face 
criticism that they’re system passers.  
 
Nine years into their respective careers, it’s reasonable to wonder whether the 2016 class is highly skilled or products of 
surrounding talent and effective schemes. The truth is that most long-term starting quarterbacks are highly skilled, and 
skilled talent still needs a good supporting cast and effective schemes to play to their potential.  
 
Goff and Wentz underwhelmed in 2020 and were traded away in 2021 because they couldn’t win from the pocket despite 
playing in offensive systems that did everything possible to minimize their weaknesses in this area. Meanwhil
analysis:
The provided text does not offer individual quarterback summaries.  It uses the 2016 quarterback draft class (Jared Goff, Carson Wentz, Dak Prescott) as an example to illustrate the pitfalls of premature quarterback evaluations in the NFL draft process.  The text highlights the following points:

* **Early evaluations are unreliable:**  Analysts often make judgments about quarterbacks too early, leading to inaccurate and misleading assessments.  A minimum of 30 games is suggested before forming a truly reliable opinion.
* **System vs. Skill:** The early hype surrounding the 2016 class masked the question of whether their success was due to inherent skill or supportive systems.  While all successful quarterbacks need good systems, the text implies the 2016 class may have been overrated in terms of individual talent.
* **Pocket Passing Ability:** Goff and Wentz's struggles in 2020, leading to trades in 2021, demonstrate the importance of pocket passing ability, an area where even quarterbacks with early success can be deficient.


The text does *not* provide individual strengths, weaknesses, opportunities, or NFL player comparisons for Goff, Wentz, or Prescott beyond the general observations mentioned above.

text:
ed in 2020 and were traded away in 2021 because they couldn’t win from the pocket despite 
playing in offensive systems that did everything possible to minimize their weaknesses in this area. Meanwhile, Dak Prescott 
proved with both his presence and absence from the field (ask Andy Dalton) that he could keep the Cowboys competitive 
while playing from leaky pockets. Prescott returned to prominence in 2021 with a healthy team in tow but had his ups and 
downs in 2022 before rebounding last year.  
 
In 2021, Wentz and Goff showed promise of reviving their careers but only Goff built on that potential in 2022.  
 
What we’ve learned is that Wentz was a system quarterback who can win with enough surrounding talent to support his 
strengths and minimize his weaknesses. Goff and Prescott are a little closer to true franchise quarterbacks.  
 
Yet, coaches deserve credit for expanding the NFL offensive canon to capitalize on the talents (and minimizing the 
weaknesses) of their quarterbacks.  
 
Wentz deserved credit for executing the system and creating when the system breaks down. However, when defenses 
figured out the schemes, the system quarterback rarely transcends the flaws of his offense.  
 
Mariota and Winston? The media praised Tennessee during Mariota’s rookie year for adjusting the offense to fit Mariota’s 
strengths. Seven years later, Mariota has been a backup or stopgap option for Oakland, Atlanta, Philadelphia, and 
Washington.  
 
Winston remained the up-and-down producer. His feet often lag behind his mind although dedicated training to address this 
issue led to promising results in 2021 before suffering season-ending injuries that have kept him out of the lineup. As a 
journeyman, Winston has started games for the Saints and Browns. He’s now a Giant sharing the quarterback room with 
Russell Wilson

analysis:
**Dak Prescott:**

* **Strengths:** Proved ability to keep team competitive even with offensive line issues;  returned to prominence with a healthy team; possesses resilience and a capacity to rebound from setbacks.
* **Opportunities:**  Continuing to build on his recent success and maintaining consistency.
* **NFL Comparison:**  A slightly above-average starting QB, potentially a high-level game manager with some boom potential.  Not quite an elite, top-tier franchise QB, but consistently solid.


**Jared Goff:**

* **Strengths:** Showed promise of career revival and built on that potential; more adaptable than Wentz. Closer to a true franchise quarterback.
* **Opportunities:**  Continuing to build on his recent success and establishing himself as a consistent top performer.
* **NFL Comparison:**  A solid, above-average starting quarterback capable of leading a team to the playoffs but possibly lacking the elite ceiling of a true superstar.


**Carson Wentz:**

* **Strengths:**  Can win with enough surrounding talent to support his strengths and minimize weaknesses; capable of creating plays when the system breaks down.
* **Opportunities:** Limited; likely requires a very specific offensive system to succeed.
* **NFL Comparison:**  A system quarterback, similar to a player who thrives in a specific scheme but struggles outside of it.  Might be compared to a slightly less successful version of previous high-potential, system-dependent quarterbacks.


**Marcus Mariota:**

* **Strengths:**  Initially benefited from an offense tailored to his strengths.
* **Opportunities:**  Limited; has primarily served as a backup or stopgap throughout his career.
* **NFL Comparison:**  A journeyman backup quarterback, not able to sustain a starting role over a long period.  Similar to several other quarterbacks drafted high who failed to live up to expectations.


**Jameis Winston:**

* **Strengths:**  Showed promise with dedicated training; displays flashes of high-level play.
* **Opportunities:**  Limited by injury and inconsistency; currently in a backup role.
* **NFL Comparison:**  A high-risk, high-reward type of quarterback with a strong arm but prone to turnovers and inconsistency.  A more volatile version of a typical journeyman QB.


**2022 Rookie QBs (Ridder, Willis, Howell, Corral):**

* **Strengths:**  N/A (passage indicates their high draft positions were "extreme projections").
* **Opportunities:**  All face an uphill battle to prove their draft positions were justified.
* **NFL Comparison:**  The passage suggests they are likely to fall short of expectations, implying comparisons to other high draft busts.  Awaiting further performance data to make a precise comparison.

In 2022, the NFL collectively realized that using first-round picks on Ridder, Malik Willis, Sam Howell, and Matt Corral were 
extreme projections. The most impressive performer — the NFL Draft’s Mr. Irrelevant, Brock Purdy – was one of two players 
the RSP was higher on than the consensus.  
 
The NFL might be getting wiser about generating early production from its young passers, but it’s not any better at 
sustaining it. Once opponents figure out what a quarterback can and can’t do, they adjust.  
 
These adjustments have a common aim: Make the quarterback physically or mentally uncomfortable in the pocket. The 
pocket will always be the setting where the quarterback makes the vast majority of his decisions. Pocket management is 
one of Purdy’s greatest skills and why he’s gone from Mr. Irrelevant to a starter that guided the 49ers to consecutive NFC 
Championship appearances and a Super Bowl.  
 
The best starting quarterbacks have enough skills to counter defensive adjustments and possess only a minimum number of 
flaws that only the best defenses can exploit. The average starting quarterback may counter some of these defensive 
adjustments but have more flaws for opposing defenses to exploit to make a game competitive.  
 

 
4 
Defenses have the advantage against below-average starting quarterbacks with at least one significant and limiting flaw. 
Unless the offense has enough game-changing players a defense must respect, the offense is doomed to struggle. 
 
Quarterback flaws are rooted in two basic areas: Diagnosis and execution.  
 
Most diagnostic activities take place in the pocket. And while execution can occur outside the pocket, the quarterback still 
has to maneuver from the pocket while reading the field to find success.  
 
Football cannot remove the pocket from the game. It can create ways to mitigate the physical punishment. It can reduce 
the time needed to play from the pocket by penalizing physi

text:
to find success.  
 
Football cannot remove the pocket from the game. It can create ways to mitigate the physical punishment. It can reduce 
the time needed to play from the pocket by penalizing physical play and slowing route development. And it can more 
frequently employ passers who can move outside the pocket and generate big plays.  
 
Even so, Patrick Mahomes—a passer with the promise of becoming the greatest quarterback of this generation—could not 
keep his team competitive in compromised pockets in Super Bowl LV. Despite showing incredible mobility outside the pocket 
and arm angles – prompting even the Tampa Bay wide receivers to express their admiration in the moment – Mahomes’ 
unbelievable play could not overcome the Chiefs’ struggles to provide him a clean pocket for most of the game. The Eagles 
capitalized on the Chiefs’ weakness this year. 
 
One of the root factors for Josh Allen’s ascendence has been his development as a pocket manager. The lesson is clear: 
Even Allen and Mahomes can’t win at the highest level without a pocket. It’s why the buzz about quarterbacks who can win 
off-structure, off-platform, and outside the pocket is exciting but just more media-generated click-bait if they can’t win from 
the pocket.  
 
The reason is simple: It often takes a quarterback longer to escape the pocket than it does to finish a drop, find an open 
receiver running his scripted route, and deliver the ball. 
 
In fact, it often takes a quarterback longer to escape the pocket than it does to finish a drop, avoid pressure within the 
pocket, reset his feet as he locates his second or third option about to break open, and deliver the ball. It’s all about the 
timing and structure of route design tied to the quarterback’s drop plan.  
 
This is why diagnostic skills within the pocket are so valuable. However, diagnostic skills in the pocket are different from 
diagnostic skills on a white board during a team visit or Combine interview.

diagnostic skills on a white board during a team visit or Combine interview.  
 
If I could pinpoint an area where a lot of teams miss with their evaluation of quarterbacks, it’s undervaluing a passer’s 
confidence. This sounds like an intangible, but it’s not when you define the term as confidence to close the gap between 
identification-to-action.  
 
The whiteboard prowess and recall of plays and coverages are a form of identification. Teams annually praise top prospects 
for their identification in these settings and it often translates to the field.  
 
Unfortunately, none of that static whiteboard identification is any good on the field if the player can’t identify what’s 
happening from the dirty sightlines of the pocket. Even if that can, they’re sunk if they lack the confidence to act at the 
immediate point of recognition isn’t there. Waiting for further confirmation of what’s immediately seen rather than acting on 
what’s immediately seen plagues a lot of early-round passers who teams annually praise for “talking about the game like 
coaches,” before the draft.  
 
This was the pre-draft praise for Desmond Ridder in 2022. The film wasn’t buying it.  
 
Keep this in mind when, for the sixth consecutive year leading up to the NFL Draft, you’ll hear the media or team tout a 
player as the next Patrick Mahomes, Josh Allen, and Lamar Jackson. There aren’t any who will be exactly like them. 
Recognize the wishful thinking from teams hoping to land the player they overlooked without truly understanding why they 
overlooked him.  
 
Wise Coaches Choose to Fit Scheme to Quarterback, Not Quarterback to Scheme

analysis:
**Josh Allen:**

* **Strengths:** Elite arm talent, vertical and crossing route passer, star-level quarterback with minimized exploitable flaws.  Has significantly improved processing skills despite his late development.
* **Opportunities:**  Continued refinement to overcome remaining challenges against zone defenses. Maintaining high level of play requires supporting cast health and limiting situations that force him away from the game plan.
* **NFL Comparison:**  A unique player, no exact comparison.  His trajectory is perhaps closer to a later-blooming, supremely talented quarterback like a slightly less accurate Patrick Mahomes.

**Baker Mayfield:**

* **Strengths:**  Improved decision-making and play under a new coaching staff and offensive system that masked his weaknesses.  Has shown a renewed commitment and perspective after leaving Cleveland.
* **Opportunities:** To continue his upward trajectory in Tampa Bay and potentially approach the level initially projected before his struggles in Cleveland.  He must consistently avoid the regression seen earlier in his career.
* **NFL Comparison:**  Initially compared to Brett Favre, Drew Brees, and Russell Wilson – comparisons deemed unrealistic early in his career.  His current play suggests a path towards a successful but perhaps not elite-level career akin to a less mobile and less accurate version of Russell Wilson.


**Lamar Jackson:**

* **Strengths:**  Earned two MVP seasons and continually proves doubters wrong.  Adaptable to evolving offensive systems and showed success outside Greg Roman's initially limiting system.
* **Opportunities:** Continued success with Todd Monken's offense, maintaining his high level of play and MVP candidacy.  Further evolution and refinement of his game to silence any remaining critics.
* **NFL Comparison:**  A unique dual-threat quarterback; a more athletic and less pocket-passing version of Russell Wilson, combined with a strong running element comparable to Michael Vick.

In 2019, Kyler Murray earned the best scheme fit in Arizona, playing in an offense tailored for him, earning him strong

struggles continued in 2020 and 2021 due to injury and Jones’ inability to sense pressure. 2022’s addition of Brian Daboll,

pro and gave him at least one more year to prove he’s a long-term answer for the Giants. Jones didn’t prove it.  
 
The Broncos made some tweaks for Drew Lock midseason, and he thrived in late 2019. But Denver struggled in 2020 
because Lock proved that he wasn’t remotely like Mahomes in or outside the pocket or in his preparation off the field. As 
mentioned in the 2020 RSP, Lock has proven he has a light-switch mindset, and teammates complained about it to local 
media. He lost his starting job to Teddy Bridgewater in 2021 and was no competition for Geno Smith in 2022.

to the WCO:  
 
The backbone of the Erhardt-Perkins system is that plays — pass plays in particular — are not organized by a route 
tree or by calling a single receiver’s route, but by what coaches refer to as “concepts.” Each play has a name, and 
that name conjures up an image for both the quarterback and the other players on offense. And, most importantly, 
the concept can be called from almost any formation or set. Who does what changes, but the theory and tactics 
driving the play do not. “In essence, you’re running the same play,” said Perkins. “You’re just giving them some 
window-dressing to make it look different.” 
The biggest advantage of the concept-based system is that it operates from the perspective of the most critical 
player on offense: the quarterback. In other systems, even if the underlying principles are the exact same, the play 
and its name might be very different. Rather than juggling all this information in real time, an Erhardt-Perkins 
quarterback only has to read a given arrangement of receivers. “You can cut down on the plays and get different 
looks from your formations and who’s in them. It’s easier for the players to learn. It’s easier for the quarterback to 
learn,” former Patriots offensive coordinator Charlie Weis said back in 2000. “You get different looks without 
changing his reads. You don’t need an open-ended number of plays.” 
This simplicity is one of the reasons coaches around the league have been gravitating to the Erhardt-Perkins 
approach. “Concepts benefit you because you can plug different guys into different formations, into different 
personnel groups, and if they understand the concept, it gives you more flexibility,” [then] Atlanta Falcons 
offensive coordinator Dirk Koetter recently explained. “The number system restricts you because it doesn’t allow 
you to cover all the combinations you want to use, so you have to get into so many tags that eventually you’re 
calling everybody’s route. In route concepts,

There are an increasing number of successful football coaches and players that believe the NFL’s old guard coordinators are 
too steeped in the WCO and Zampese schemes. According to coaches I have spoken to, the old guards’ egos are 
(understandably) tied to these systems, because it’s the method they used to build their careers.  
 
But these offenses were successful when there was more continuity in the league and patience with coaches and players 
was longer. Because coaches see these systems as part of their personal success and job security, they fear embracing a 
significant change in systems. This fear-based intractability is especially present when the talent they acquire has a proven 
track record with different methods.  
 
The risk of fitting scheme to player instead of player to scheme can be daunting for a coach with this attitude. It’s easier to 
sit at the top of the career mountain and claim the college schemes won’t work.  
 
It’s safer to make young players climb the mountain rather than meet the player halfway for the long-term benefit of the 
team and potentially look inept with a new way of doing things. This is especially true if you know that your job security 
isn’t with your current team. Based on current turnover rates, the team will likely fire you in a few years unless you’ve 
managed to sustain playoff success. True job security rests in securing a reputation that will make you a safe hire for 
another team after you’re fired from your current team.

strength. He got away with it on Saturdays, because pinpoint accuracy is not a requirement for consistent success in the 
college game. The higher standards for accuracy on Sunday magnified his issues in the NFL.

could deliver quick-hitting reads tied to one-step setups. While not the entire answer for Wentz’s second-year improvement,

Capitalizing on These Changes as a Fantasy Player 
 
I normally believe the best way to approach rookie quarterbacks in dynasty leagues, in this era of football, is to avoid most 
of them early -- regardless of their NFL draft capital. Every year there will be exceptional cases. Last year, there were three 
I thought were worth an early investment risk. This year, there’s one.  
 
Still, I have no problem recommending avoiding them all. Fantasy GMs will still benefit from stockpiling wide receiver and 
running back talent with the plan of eventually trading these easy-to-deal players for an established quarterback.  
 
Usually, drafting a rookie quarterback in your fantasy league should be considered a luxury pick. The position rarely 
provides immediate return in a starting lineup or the trade market unless it’s a Super-flex format. Stockpiling other 
positions could be more helpful because you have more opportunity to trade for quarterbacks you desire.

talent evaluations but also with draft capital and fit in mind.

projections service for the fantasy-obsessed. It’s a quality service for those who want to leverage “present” thinking with a 
dash of long-term consideration, especially for the trade market.  
 
That said, I am still a believer that what you’re reading right now is by far the best long-term analysis because it’s rooted 
first and foremost in film-based analysis.

text:
ess than 50 percent, and referencing Dan Hatman’s research above, scouting and 
developing quarterbacks is the remaining untamed wilderness in the league.  
 
Several years ago, I also examined first-round quarterbacks. I looked at 20 years of first-round picks since 1993—not 
counting 2013 or 2014. There were 51 quarterbacks selected in the first round. Only 22 were what I call “good starters.” 
Here are the criteria: 
 
• 
Led his team to the playoffs at least once.  
• 
Earned at least one trip to the Pro Bowl. 
• 
Earned top-five statistical production in meaningful passing categories (yards, touchdowns, and completion 
percentage) more than once. 
 
The success rate for a first-round quarterback since 1993 is 45 percent — worse odds than a coin flip — but slightly higher 
than Dan Hatman’s 34 percent rate for all first-round players. When I raised the bar to “star”, which I would expect to get if 
I invested a top-15 pick in the draft, the success rate for all first-round passers dropped to 17 percent.  
 
You can read the rest here, but the takeaway from this exercise is that a major investment in quarterbacks does not yield a 
worthwhile return. My definition of “star” is a soft standard. The first-round picks that met the criteria include: Drew 
Bledsoe, Steve McNair, Donovan McNabb, Peyton Manning, Ben Roethlisberger, Philip Rivers, Daunte Culpepper and Aaron 
Rodgers.  
 
Of those eight, McNair, Culpepper, Rivers and Rodgers were not starters as rookies. McNabb only started six games. 
Roethlisberger and Bledsoe started most of their games, but not all of them.  
 
Since this examination there have been 20 first-round quarterbacks from 2013-19 (not counting the past two years, so 
there’s a cushion for acclimation time) and 12 (60%) of them are qualifies to these standards: Kyler Murray, Baker 
Mayfield, Josh Allen, Patrick Mahomes, Deshaun Watson, Lamar Jackson, Jared Goff, Carson Wentz, Jameis Winston, Marcus 
Mariota, Mitchell Trubisky, and Blake Bortle

Although there’s a slight chance of another opportunity to prove otherwise, only one of the three remotely played to a Pro 
Bowl or top-five statistical level with their new teams and it’s unlikely the other two will return to their peak performances 
that were too fleeting to count them as “good starters.”  
 
Even with the addition of 2013-19, it’s a small sample size. Of course, the sample size of the highest quality of any resource 
— from diamonds to truffles to NFL quarterbacks — tends to be small. And this woeful success rate leads me to question the 
logic behind impulsive, owner-driven mandates that first-round rookies must start Year One. Is the NFL doing more harm 
than good with its coveted investments?  
 
The counterargument is that college quarterbacks are better developed physically than previous generations of athletes. But 
the return on investment doesn’t reflect these supposed advantages. The growth of the spread offense was an area where 
the NFL attempted to shift the blame, but teams are adopting its principles with the hope of easing the acclimation period.  
 
There’s a gap in logic about quarterback play in the NFL. No matter what teams say, they draft these players with the 
expectation to be the face of the franchise for the next decade. That’s at least two contracts and likely 1-2 contract 
extensions in terms of time.  
 
However, they also want these players to start right away and succeed immediat

However, they also want these players to start right away and succeed immediately when any astute fan knows what 
coaches know: It takes 18-24 games to even get a sense of the quarterback’s development curve, decide where his ceiling 
of skill will be, and what’s necessary from the scheme and surrounding talent to aid or sustain his play. 
 
One can make a compelling argument that in terms of talent and production, Drew Brees, Tom Brady, Aaron Rodgers, 
Patrick Mahomes, and Josh Allen are the best quarterbacks drafted since 2000. Lamar Jackson arguably belongs on this list 
after earning two MVP awards.  
 
Matt Ryan, Deshaun Watson, Cam Newton, Russell Wilson, Mike Vick, Andrew Luck, Ben Roethlisberger, and Phillip Rivers 
deserve consideration, but they aren’t in that rarefied air of the five mentioned. Wilson and Watson were close for a time 
and could get there, and Newton had a few years of excellent play, but there are arguments against each for this tier.  
 
Regardless, Brady, Brees, and Rodgers all sat behind veterans for at least a year before earning a shot. Mahomes, too. 
Jackson sat for most of his rookie year as well. If you add Wilson and Watson to this tier, you’re talking about two-thirds of 
the most talented and accomplished passers we’ve seen in two decades. Yet, the league behaves as if picking the right

Business sponsors of teams also offer endorsement contracts to young players before they’ve proven anything.  
• 
Criticism from local and national media (with the same companies sponsoring these shows) for making a big 
investment in a player sitting on the bench, when other franchises put theirs on the field immediately.  
• 
TV ratings — fans watch when there is at least reason to look to the future. High ratings for the NFL translate to 
maintaining top-dollar TV contracts.  
• 
Merchandise sales – especially jerseys of young quarterbacks getting all this free marketing from the media. 
 
Owners are businessmen and businessmen need profits. “Winning” for an owner is more than the organization’s record on 
the field. Licensing, affiliations, new stadiums, and TV contracts are grand victories that outweigh the money earned from 
winning a championship. Some owners seek these business wins more avidly than on-field victories.  
 
The numbers demonstrate that owners don’t need to mandate that rookie quarterbacks start because the success rate is 
low. But these players will continue being shoved into lineups too soon. And I acknowledge that there have been players 
who were more than ready to succeed. I don’t have amnesia; I evaluated them.  
 
Coaches make these mandates work in their favor — regardless of how ready these quarterbacks truly are — by creating 
systems that smooth the transition and yield production for the quarterbacks and their fantasy owners.  
 
After Robert Griffin III, Andrew Luck and Russell Wilson entered the league, the average seasonal fantasy points scored for 
the top-12 fantasy rookie performances jumped 26 points. All three players had pragmatic coaches tailor the offense to 
their talents like few have before them.  
 
Despite the dominance of the West Coast Offense, we’re seeing teams move to other systems. Within a few years I’ll revisit 
this look at first-round quarterbacks, and I believe we may see more coaches tailor offense
analysis:
This text doesn't provide individual quarterback summaries. Instead, it discusses the business pressures and coaching strategies surrounding rookie quarterbacks in the NFL.  The author highlights the following:

**Key Points:**

* **Business Drivers:**  Team owners prioritize profitability beyond on-field wins.  Rookie quarterbacks generate revenue through endorsements, merchandise sales, and increased TV ratings (even if they aren't successful on the field immediately).  This incentivizes starting rookies early, despite the low success rate.

* **Coaching Strategies:** Coaches adapt offensive systems to suit rookie quarterbacks' talents, increasing their production and fantasy value.  This is illustrated by the success of Robert Griffin III, Andrew Luck, and Russell Wilson, whose coaches tailored offenses to their strengths.  A shift away from the West Coast Offense is predicted, favoring more customized systems.

* **The Problem:**  While acknowledging some rookie quarterbacks are ready, the author emphasizes the financial incentives that lead to prematurely starting many others, regardless of their preparedness.


The text doesn't offer individual quarterback analyses or comparisons; it focuses on the broader context influencing their early-career experiences.

text:
inance of the West Coast Offense, we’re seeing teams move to other systems. Within a few years I’ll revisit 
this look at first-round quarterbacks, and I believe we may see more coaches tailor offenses to their quarterbacks.  
 
Dak Prescott worked in a Cowboys scheme that’s fundamentally the Erhardt-Perkins with doses of Air Coryell-influenced 
ideas. Patrick Mahomes dominated in a spread offense that adapted a lot of Texas Tech’s scheme. Jared Goff, Mitchell 
Trubisky, Carson Wentz, Lamar Jackson, Kyler Murray, Jalen Hurts, Joe Burrow, and Justin Herbert had promising starts in 
offenses tailored to them.  
 
If teams continue trending away from the West Coast Offense in favor of simpler to learn systems, drafting rookie 
quarterbacks may no longer be as risky. That is, if you define risk as quick results that aren’t sustainable. Think of it as a 
fad diet that leads to a yo-yo effect and eventually the person who originally buys into the plan gives up on it. 
 
Hey Chicago, tired of mourning the long-gone Sid Luckman era? Try the Trubisky Plan! Looks and moves like a real 
quarterback! Possible side effects: haphazard decision-making, difficulty learning from mistakes, and a complete lack of 
intuitive play may lead to heartburn, upset stomachs, and mild depression.  
 
Tennessee, the Mariota Strategy will give you quick results that remind you of your glory days with Steve McNair! 
 
Back to you, Chicago! Got Justin Fields, eh? Pair him with a coach that makes Fields climb the mountain to the coach’s 
scheme rather than matching the scheme to Fields’ talents. What? That didn’t work well? Who would have known… 
 
Warning: Quick results aren’t sustainable unless there’s considerable development in Years Two and Three to outpace the 
adjustments that opponents will make to counter what they see on film during the first 16-24 games. Otherwise, this 
product is only recommended for a quick and temporary boost.  
 
Continuity is also an important part of the equation.

It’s a not so dirty little secret that too many NFL owners and executives play billionaire-level fantasy football with their 
organizations: countermanding months of scouting and consensus building and basing organizational decisions on what talk-
media thinks, the flash of NFL Combine Drills and Pro Days, and even grudges against cities that didn’t want to cow-tow to 
their ever-increasing corporate welfare demands.  
 
Johnny Manziel, Zach Wilson, Alex Smith, and Vince Young are all telling examples of these gaffes. If you haven’t heard the 
stories from me on podcasts, you can find them documented in major publications.

Teams are seeing the early success of quarterbacks outside the mold of pure pocket passers that dominate NFL history from 
Johnny Unitas and Joe Namath to Peyton Manning and Tom Brady. The league has adopted a broader view of who can play 
quarterback. Still, C.J. Stroud, 2023’s top-performing rookie, is a classic pocket quarterback.  
 
Robert Griffin III working from the Pistol forced defenses to account for the Baylor star’s incredible athleticism and ball-
handling precision on fakes and drops. Griffin’s dynamic skill helped Washington create single-coverage matchups that gave 
him more open passing lanes than what he would have enjoyed in more condensed, traditional sets. Despite his lack of 
sustained success, Griffin opened the gates for Kyler Murray, Dak Prescott, Lamar Jackson, and Deshaun Watson to make 
this list.  
 
Over time, the NFL catches up to the novelties of these changes if the talent of the player isn’t truly elite. Marcus Mariota 
posted the 12th-best total among rookie quarterbacks, but he was only 22nd overall among scorers at his position for the 
2015 season.  
 
Of these spread players on the list, only Griffin and Murray earned top-10 production among their peers. Griffin was an elite 
athlete when healthy and his system was new to the league. Murray is also an elite athlete and Kliff Kingsbury’s offense also

* **NFL Player Comparison:** Russell Wilson (though the text notes this comparison was once viewed negatively by analyst Greg Cosell, suggesting a shift in perspective towards mobile QBs).


**Josh Allen, Jalen Hurts, Lamar Jackson, Justin Fields:**

* **Strengths:** All possess substantial passing skills *and* significant rushing abilities, representing the modern ideal of a dual-threat quarterback.
* **Opportunities:**  Their skill sets are highly valued and sought-after in today's NFL.
* **NFL Player Comparisons:** The text doesn't provide specific comparisons, but they are all implicitly compared to each other as representatives of this new archetype of mobile quarterbacks.


**Anthony Richardson:**

* **Strengths:** The text implies he has the potential to be a game-breaking dual-threat quarterback.
* **Opportunities:**  High potential given his athleticism, but also potential for significant growth.
* **NFL Player Comparison:**  No comparison is offered, highlighting his unique potential.


**Overall Summary:**

The text argues that the NFL has seen a significant shift in the desired quarterback profile.  While pocket passers still have a place, the modern game increasingly values dual-threat quarterbacks with strong passing and rushing capabilities.  Players like Murray, Allen, Hurts, Jackson, and Fields exemplify this shift, while Richardson represents the potential for even more dynamic players to emerge.  The text suggests a broader acceptance of this new archetype, contrasting it with previous standards where mobile quarterbacks may have been relegated to alternative leagues or different positions.

text:
urray, Josh Allen, Jalen Hurts, Lamar Jackson, and Justin Fields all have substantial skills as passers but also can generate 
impressive totals with their legs. Anthony Richardson has a chance to be added to this list soon enough. Jayden Daniels got  
off to a good start. So did Bo Nix. Jalen Milroe is a good bet to join them in a year or two.  
 
The marquee talents, according to projected draft capital, in this year’s class are a mix of traditional drop-back passers, 
pocket passers with enough athletic ability to run for big plays (gains of 15-30 yards), and a breakaway runner with a 
decent arm in Daniels.   
 
Teams can make it easier—and prevent early failures that kill the player’s potential too soon—with the help of a good 
scheme. However, there’s a point beyond the first 12-18 games of a player’s career that the defenses knock the training 
wheels off. 
 
One of the players on this top rookie scorer list is still in the league but isn’t an NFL starter (Winston). Mayfield has revived 
his career. Wilson is entering journeyman status, but still capable.   
 
At this point, the quarterback must show that he’s more than a product of his system and his surrounding talent. Based on 
what we’ve seen over the past 6-7 years, the NFL is getting the system part of the equation right but it’s only half the 
answer, at best.  
 
 
 
Quarterbacks Draft by Round (2015-2024) 
 
For the past decade, we’ve seen a predictable number of quarterbacks taken in the NFL Draft.

starter this year or next. There are six organizations in the market for a new starter:

Arizona: Kyler Murray is under contract through 2029, but there’s an out in 2028. Still, Murray hasn’t supported 
starter production for multiple receivers for the vast majority of his career and the Cardinals aren’t winning with 
him. They’re likely tied to him, but adding more QB talent could make Murray tradable.  
• 
Cleveland: Deshaun Watson is an emotional shell of what he once was and Kenny Pickett hasn’t shown enough to 
build around him.  
• 
Detroit: Jared Goff is likely two-thirds into his career, but Hendon Hooker is unproven and, from the RSP’s point of 
view, not a strong heir apparent.  
• 
Las Vegas: Geno Smith is a win-now addition and at age 34, likely a bridge starter to help guide a young 
quarterback. It’s unlikely Aidan O’Connell and Carter Bradley are long-term answers.  
• 
L.A. Rams: Maybe Stetson Bennett is a long-term answer, but it’s unlikely.  
• 
Miami: Is Zach Wilson a reclamation project for Mike McDaniel? I doubt it.  
• 
Minnesota: J.J. McCarthy might be the answer, but there’s no one else and he’s unproven.  
• 
New Orleans: The Saints have a potential out with Derek Carr this year—as unlikely as it is they take it.  
• 
N.Y. Jets: Not a good place for a young QB right now, but it’s conceivable they’ll be shopping for a rookie.  
• 
Pittsburgh: Having Skylar Thompson behind Aaron Rodgers (not signed as of writing this) is appealing to me, but 
this is a good scenario for a young talent to sit.

Seattle: Sam Darnold exorcised the ghosts in Minnesota, but if the Seahawks’ front office doesn’t build a

analysis:
Here's a summary of each quarterback mentioned, highlighting strengths, opportunities, and NFL player comparisons:

**Arizona Cardinals: Kyler Murray**

* **Strengths:**  Exceptional athleticism and arm talent.
* **Opportunities:**  A potential trade if the Cardinals add more QB talent, allowing a fresh start elsewhere.
* **Weaknesses:** Inconsistent performance, hasn't consistently elevated supporting receivers, and team lacks wins.
* **NFL Comparison:** A less consistent, more injury-prone version of Russell Wilson (early career).


**Cleveland Browns: Deshaun Watson & Kenny Pickett**

* **Deshaun Watson:**
    * **Strengths:**  Proven talent, when on the field.
    * **Weaknesses:**  Off-field issues significantly impacted performance and mental state; lacks current consistency.
    * **Opportunities:** None mentioned, but a potential rebound could happen if he fully addresses personal issues.
    * **NFL Comparison:** A shadow of his former self, similar to a past-prime Brett Favre (without the longevity and wins).

* **Kenny Pickett:**
    * **Strengths:**  None explicitly stated; implied lack of proof of becoming a franchise QB.
    * **Weaknesses:** Hasn't demonstrated the talent to build around him.
    * **Opportunities:**  To prove his worth as a starter; a long shot.
    * **NFL Comparison:**  A less talented version of several journeyman quarterbacks.


**Detroit Lions: Jared Goff & Hendon Hooker**

* **Jared Goff:**
    * **Strengths:** Experienced, capable starter.
    * **Weaknesses:** Likely nearing the end of his prime.
    * **Opportunities:**  To continue leading a successful Lions team.
    * **NFL Comparison:** A solid, above-average game manager, similar to a less dynamic Matthew Stafford.

* **Hendon Hooker:**
    * **Strengths:**  None explicitly stated, considered unproven.
    * **Weaknesses:**  Unproven at the NFL level, not seen as a strong heir apparent.
    * **Opportunities:**  To prove himself in practice and potentially compete for a starting role later.
    * **NFL Comparison:**  Difficult to compare at this stage, too early to tell.


**Las Vegas Raiders: Geno Smith, Aidan O’Connell, & Carter Bradley**

* **Geno Smith:**
    * **Strengths:**  Proven starter, capable of leading a team.
    * **Weaknesses:** Age (34); likely a temporary solution.
    * **Opportunities:** To mentor younger quarterbacks and lead the Raiders to short-term success.
    * **NFL Comparison:** A journeyman QB who exceeded expectations, akin to a less talented Drew Brees.

* **Aidan O’Connell & Carter Bradley:**
    * **Strengths:** None explicitly stated; implied lack of potential.
    * **Weaknesses:** Unlikely to be long-term solutions.
    * **Opportunities:** To learn and potentially develop into a backup role.
    * **NFL Comparison:**  Difficult to compare, too early to tell.


**L.A. Rams: Stetson Bennett**

* **Stetson Bennett:**
    * **Strengths:** None explicitly stated; considered an unlikely long-term answer.
    * **Weaknesses:**  Unlikely to be a long-term solution.
    * **Opportunities:** To prove himself as a capable backup.
    * **NFL Comparison:**  Difficult to compare, too early to tell.


**Miami Dolphins: Zach Wilson**

* **Zach Wilson:**
    * **Strengths:** None explicitly stated; considered a failed reclamation project.
    * **Weaknesses:**  Unlikely to succeed in Miami.
    * **Opportunities:** Minimal to none.
    * **NFL Comparison:**  A bust, similar to several high-draft QBs who failed to live up to the hype.


**Minnesota Vikings: J.J. McCarthy**

* **J.J. McCarthy:**
    * **Strengths:** Potential, but unproven.
    * **Weaknesses:**  Lack of proven talent and supporting cast.
    * **Opportunities:** To develop into a franchise quarterback, but faces a high degree of uncertainty.
    * **NFL Comparison:**  Too early to tell; potential to become a good QB, but currently unproven.


**New Orleans Saints: Derek Carr**

* **Derek Carr:**
    * **Strengths:** Experienced starting quarterback.
    * **Weaknesses:**  Team might have a potential out this year, making him a short-term solution.
    * **Opportunities:** To continue leading the Saints, but his future is uncertain.
    * **NFL Comparison:**  A consistently average QB, similar to a less successful Philip Rivers.


**N.Y. Jets:** No specific QB mentioned, but team is implied to be shopping for a rookie.

**Pittsburgh Steelers: Skylar Thompson & Aaron Rodgers**

* **Skylar Thompson:**
    * **Strengths:** Appealing as a backup to a veteran.
    * **Weaknesses:**  Likely a backup QB.
    * **Opportunities:** To learn from Rodgers and potentially become a starter in the future.
    * **NFL Comparison:**  A career backup.

* **Aaron Rodgers:**  (Not yet signed at the time of writing) His comparison would depend on his level of play post-Green Bay.


**Seattle Seahawks: Sam Darnold**

* **Sam Darnold:**
    * **Strengths:** Showed improvement in Minnesota.
    * **Weaknesses:**  Needs a strong supporting cast to succeed.
    * **Opportunities:** To continue improving and establish himself as a long-term starter.
    * **NFL Comparison:** A journeyman QB with untapped potential, similar to a less successful version of several franchise QBs.


**Tampa Bay Buccaneers: Baker Mayfield & Kyle Trask**

* **Baker Mayfield:**
    * **Strengths:** Proven starting QB.
    * **Weaknesses:**  Inconsistency throughout career.
    * **Opportunities:**  To re-establish himself as a successful starter.
    * **NFL Comparison:**  Similar to many journeyman QBs who show flashes of brilliance but lack consistency.

* **Kyle Trask:**
    * **Strengths:** None explicitly stated; considered to have no future as a starter.
    * **Weaknesses:**  No future with the Buccaneers.
    * **Opportunities:**  Limited opportunities.
    * **NFL Comparison:**  Likely to be a career backup or out of the NFL.

Unless offensive coordinators develop an answer that catches fire early, expect lower production values this year as well

Prescott and Wilson were glaring exceptions to the usual mediocre numbers for starting rookie passers selected after the 
opening two rounds of the draft. The corresponding production among the quarterbacks in each round reinforces this 
tendency.  
 
Draft capital is not a clean predictor of talent, but there’s an absolute correlation to extended opportunity for a player. If a 
player drafted after the first two rounds earns an opportunity to start and maintains that role for more than a game or two, 
it’s an indication that they have the talent to produce at an equal or greater level than their first-round peers.  
 
Last year being the exception, the last 8-10 seasons have shown rookie quarterbacks should not be counted on as 
consistent producers from beginning

Therefore, I cannot summarize individual quarterbacks' strengths, opportunities, and NFL player comparisons based solely on this data.  The text focuses on general trends rather than specific player analyses.

Here's what the text *does* tell us:


**General Trends and Observations:**

* **Draft Capital and Opportunity:**  The text strongly suggests a correlation between draft position (rounds 1 and 2) and opportunity.  Higher draft picks are more likely to start and maintain starting roles, regardless of talent.  However, players drafted later who *do* secure starting roles often perform comparably to their higher-drafted counterparts, indicating that draft capital isn't the sole predictor of success.  Russell Wilson and Dak Prescott are cited as exceptions to the general trend of poor performance from later-round rookie starters.

* **Rookie Quarterback Production:**  Rookie quarterbacks, regardless of draft position, are generally inconsistent performers. The statistics show considerable variation in passing yards, touchdowns, and interceptions, with later rounds generally exhibiting lower production.  The text cautions against relying on rookie quarterbacks for consistent production.

* **Average Performance by Round:** The data shows a clear drop-off in average production from Round 1 to subsequent rounds.  Round 1 quarterbacks, on average, significantly out-perform those drafted in later rounds. However, the exceptions mentioned (Prescott and Wilson) highlight that the lower rounds can produce high-performing quarterbacks, albeit less frequently.

In short, the text emphasizes the importance of opportunity linked to draft position while acknowledging that talented quarterbacks can emerge from any round.  Without individual player data, specific comparisons and strengths/weaknesses cannot be addressed.

text:
or greater level than their first-round peers.  
 
Last year being the exception, the last 8-10 seasons have shown rookie quarterbacks should not be counted on as 
consistent producers from beginning to end in their first seasons, but there are options that will have stretches of strong 
play. First-year quarterbacks with a good system fit and surrounding talent are worth the risk as late-round, re-draft options 
in fantasy football.  
 
Defenses aren’t as prepared for these players during their first season. There’s at least a four-week lag before opposing 
teams begin applying scouting reports of young players into their game plan. If a young quarterback doesn’t struggle early, 
fantasy GMs will have at least a month of quality production before opponents use the tape to game-plan against them with 
special tweaks.  
 
Dak Prescott’s career has had an impact on how I study quarterbacks for this publication. Although we’re nearing the point 
that I will be retiring this explanation as to why, it’s still worth sharing how Prescott’s rookie year changed my process 
almost a decade ago.  
 
This includes the expansion of my game charting methods so I could take a closer look at accuracy. Although sample sizes 
are small and potentially problematic, the expansion of my charting has helped me improve my contextualization of 
individual quarterback accuracy.  
 
Fans and media analysts place too much weight on exciting throws that are a reflection of great arm talent. However, we 
inadvertently can place too much weight on the talent of the arm and not the rest of the quarterback. This is especially the 
case when the throws that many celebrate are low-percentage plays and don’t make the difference nearly as often as the 
highlights make it appear.  
 
 
 
Making Sense of Dak Prescott (And How It Changed the Future of the RSP)

text:
ak Prescott (And How It Changed the Future of the RSP) 
 
I don’t normally revisit a player after his first season. We’ve seen players become the darlings of the NFL for a season only 
to disappoint for the remainder of their careers. Derek Anderson and Steve Slaton come to mind immediately.  
 
But there was a wide enough gap between Prescott’s rookie performance in Dallas and my assessment of him at Mississippi 
State to motivate me to revisit my evaluation. There appeared to be a logical explanation for Prescott’s first month.  
 
Without Dez Bryant early on, the Cowboys told Prescott to play a safe two-man game with Jason Witten and Cole Beasley 
against the short and intermediate zones. After all, 12-yard runs and 16-yard passes constitute explosive plays in the NFL. 
According to research from Packers’ former Head of Research and Development Mike Eayrs, teams with just one explosive 
play during a drive score 29 percent of the time. That rate of success jumps to 77 percent with two. Without a 12-yard run 
or 16-yard pass, an offense’s rate of scoring drops to 9 percent.  
 
With Dallas’ excellent offensive line, Ezekiel Elliott’s skills, and two excellent middle-of-the-field receivers, it only made 
sense that the Cowboys could successfully minimize high-risk plays, pound defenses, keep its defense fresh, and keep 
games close into the fourth quarter. This is especially true when most NFL teams have a gap of four weeks before scouts’ 
first set of advanced reports on the rest of the NFL turn up in a coach’s office.

Far from it.

relatively new Depth of Talent grading scale over the years, I’ve found that a score of 75 or higher is usually a player with 
the materials to develop into a long-term starter.

believe the score would have been a more logical, defensible evaluation.

rookie, it helped me discover gaps in my process that I otherwise might not have seen and attributed to years of

What I Have Gained from Revisiting Prescott’s Tape  
 
I feel good knowing that three of the five areas that could have been scored higher fell on the borderline to another tier. For 
me, it indicates that I wasn’t blind to what the player could do as much as I lacked confidence in his ability to consistently 
do it.  
 
Where I saw potentially actionable measures to improve my process moving forward was volume of game study. Because 
Prescott demonstrated behaviors on the borderline of two tiers, I beleived those three additional games would have made a 
difference with my grade if I had studied them in 2016.  
 
Additionally, it means I must changed how I watched quarterbacks. In order to do this, I will be abandoned play-by-play 
notes. This was not a big deal for 99.9 percent of my readers. These were raw notes that I never edited and could count on 
one hand the number of people who told me that they actually read them. 

 
18 
 
While I discussed that I transcribed every play, I never marketed them as must-read material. The process was for me.  
 
Writing down every possible thing of relevancy I noticed with every player, for the first 12 seasons of the publication was a 
great football education. As the number of details I noticed grew with each passing year, the unintended consequences 
began to outweigh the benefits.  
 
The note-taking was a huge reason that my knowledge of the game grew at an accelerated rate. If you write down as much 
as you can observe about every play of a player and use that information to formulate questions and find answers for even 
one year, you’ll get smarter about the game. For that matter, you’ll become better informed about anything you study in 
this fashion.

Transcription is something I learned to do as a young musician. It’s one of dozens of reasons why my musical education in 
Miami remains an invaluable resource of knowledge and wisdom in my life, despite the fact that I no longer perform.  
 
The exercise helped me refine my process because I’d encounter things my criteria didn’t sufficiently define. I also felt that 
showing all of my work to the football community would eventually earn me street cred and help me market the publication.  
 
As a former operations manager, who earned a certification in process improvement methods, these were all benefits I 
anticipated would happen. I didn’t consider that the more I saw, the more I would write. And the more I would write, the 
more time it would take to watch film.  
 
Then, there was the matter of parsing through the volumes of notes collected on each player to finalize the scouting reports 
for this publication. That part along became madness.  
 
This is especially true when it comes to quarterbacks. Beginning with the 2018 class, stopped providing play-by-play notes 
on every player. RSP subscribers still get the grading checklists, but the time it takes for me to write play-by-play info is 
now spent watching more games of more players and devoting valuable time to my continuing education about the game. 
 
I still do play-by-play work, because transcription still helps me accumulate knowledge and refine my process, but I’m 
finding that I’m getting more from the process when I’m doing it less often. Dak Prescott is a notable lesson.

19 
About 2025’s Quarterback Rankings 
 
The RSP now has two grading scales: Depth of Talent and Breadth of Talent.  
 
The traditional checklist that has been around since the RSP began remains in place. It measures the number of things that 
a player can do at his position. This has become known as the Breadth of Talent Score.  
 
The RSP’s Skill Breakdowns have evolved into a measure of how well a player can perform those skills according to defined 
tiers of performance expectations. Weights have been assigned to the tiers and like the checklist, there is a total score. This 
is known as the Depth of Talent Score. 
 
The Checklist Score is the Breadth of Talent Score, while the Skill Breakdowns generate the Depth of Talent 
Score. The RSP will be using the Depth of Talent Score to build its player rankings. 
 
Because the Depth of Talent Score awards small bonuses to players who show developmental potential in specific areas, the 
RSP will also provide a table that ranks players without the projection bonuses. This third table will provide readers 
additional context about where I see these players now and what I foresee from them in the future.

How I Create My Rankings and the Difference Between Pre-Draft and 
Post-Draft Rankings 
 
 
In addition to its utility for fantasy football, rankings are a helpful exercise for any evaluator or draftnik. Describing my 
rankings process should also provide additional insight and usefulness to the fantasy owner. I want my readers to see some 
of the nuance behind the ranking of a player.  
 
Rankings Creation 
 
The first step is watching football. I watch hundreds of games each year—recorded broadcasts, individual cutups produced 
on YouTube, in recent years an extensive resource of All-22 film. I grade players in each session with a checklist of criteria.  
 
I try to grade a player at least twice and this year the average games graded is usually 2-4 times that amount. In many 
cases, I grade 8-10 games. Still, what’s more important to me than the number of games is the amount of touches, 
attempts, or targets that I can see in a game. I’m seeking the greatest variety of scenarios that the player has experienced.  
 
While it will always remain a work in progress—that’s the nature of process improvement—there are years of work behind 
the RSP grading system. I don’t have to think as hard about how I grade a player, because the process is defined well 
enough for me to follow it without questioning it all the time. The questions I do have come about as an organic part of the 
process and they’re helpful in making the RSP a better publication. 
 
The overall grade on this checklist is what I call a Breadth of Talent Score. This is an assessment of a player’s physical, 
mental, and technical skills that meet the baseline requirements of an NFL player at his position. The higher the score, the 
less fundamental work he must do to meet the bro

There is no information about specific quarterbacks or their strengths, weaknesses, opportunities, or NFL player comparisons.

text:

mental, and technical skills that meet the baseline requirements of an NFL player at his position. The higher the score, the 
less fundamental work he must do to meet the broad standards of the position’s requirements.  
 
The Breadth of Talent Score has a “Yes/No” grade. The score does not indicate how well the player performs the criteria on 
the checklist. This is where the Skill Breakdown comes into play (see the next section for more information).  
 
I place each player in tiers for each category of the Skill Breakdown report. All tiers are defined in a manner to differentiate 
levels of skill. I also note the ease and/or difficulty required to improve each facet of that player’s game. This exercise gives 
me insight into whether the player’s current depth of skill is at, above, or below the acceptable NFL baseline.  
 
Each tier has a weight number, and the sum of these tiers is the Depth of Talent Score. This grade is a reflection of how 
good that player is—and with a conservative, short-term projection of reasonable development—can become.  
 
A player with a high Breadth of Talent Score is versatile in the sense that he performs a broad enough range of tasks at a 
fundamentally sound level to appeal to a wide range of ways that teams define the position. A player with a high Depth of 
Talent Score at least does a subset of things at a high enough level that with the right team fit, he can become an asset.  
 
Rankings are based on Depth of Talent, because I’d prefer the idea that teams understand themselves enough to pick 
players capable of fitting into their scheme. This is not always the case, and throughout the history of the league there are 
glaring errors in judgment where the team overestimated the player’s breadth of talent, because they admired his depth of 
talent in a specific subset of areas.

20 
 
It’s difficult to assess how well a prospect will handle the transition to a professional environment without a formal 
interview, visit, and background investigation. In addition to the differences in competition, scrutiny, and pressure, the level 
of football strategy also jumps a notch. These players have a lot to learn.  
 
Some players view this transition to the NFL as an opportunity to have fewer distractions from their development plan. 
Others find even more opportunities for distraction now that they are free from the constraints of the hourly schedule that 
universities impose on them.  
 
Then there’s the unofficial mental disorder of fame, which can wreak havoc on an individual’s sense of self, his 
accountability, his routine, and his expectations of others. Many players mature through this transition as professionals with 
a craftsman’s approach to development, but others get swept away in a fast, outsized lifestyle and don’t figure out their 
responsibilities until it’s too late. And a few walk to the edge of the cliff, look Career Death in the eye, and turn around with 
enough time to make the most of their opportunity. Even the NFL hasn’t figured it out. 
 
The Difference Between Pre-Draft and Post-Draft Rankings 
 
In most cases, I prefer the pre-draft rankings. They may lack the context of the NFL Draft, but they are the purest 
assessment of talent I provide.  
 
A player I rank in my top 12 at a position can go undrafted, earn limited reps at the rear of the depth chart, get cut, and 
bounce around the league for two years before he lands on a team that recognizes his talent and gives him a real shot. The 
players I just described were NFL running backs Joique Bell and Spencer Ware. 
 
The Pre-Draft RSP rankings do not account for character or projected round. Ware fell in the draft due to character 
concerns, but this did not change his talent ranking in the R

The Pre-Draft RSP rankings do not account for character or projected round. Ware fell in the draft due to character 
concerns, but this did not change his talent ranking in the RSP. The NFL Draft is as much an exercise of risk management 
and investing as it is a talent assessment.  
 
The pre-draft rankings are free of those biases, making this publication a worthwhile reference in future seasons. Players 
don’t figure it all out on the same timeline and they often find new homes, better scheme fits, and gain maturity on the 
second or third team they join.  
 
As much as I favor the pre-draft process, post-draft rankings provide the clearest picture of the way teams see these 
players and the immediate opportunities they will earn. The post-draft rankings will account for the largest percentage of 
prospects and how their careers will play out.  
 
However, the pre-draft rankings provide a safety net when the NFL over- or underestimates talent and fit. Not only does 
this happen more than you’d think, but it also gives the reader opportunity to capitalize on these exceptional cases.  
 
Conventionality may prevent colossal failure, but exceptionality is the key to massive success. The rankings and information 
in each publication are designed to account for both dynamics as they unfold in football.

technique as defined in the glossary of the publication. What it does not do is differentiate how much or little of that 
technique each player has. Trevor Lawrence and Zach Wilson can both throw accurately on the move, but the checklist 
“yes/no” doesn’t capture the degree of accuracy.  
 
The skill breakdown reports are an avenue to explore these comparisons. The defining criteria for these breakdowns are in 
the glossary.

“Ease of Fix” for Quarterback Skill Sets 
 
It’s important to remember that athletes often enter their prime in their mid-to-late twenties, which is attributable to a 
combination of increased physical, technical, and conceptual skill.  
 
The style of the type that I used for a player’s name listed in these categories indicates a prospect’s potential to improve 
within these skill sets:  
 
• 
Normal Type: Little to no change projected as this player transitions to the NFL.  
• 
Easy Fix: These skills can improve with ease to moderate ease if the player makes the effort.  
• 
Hard Fix: These skills typically take great effort to address, if possible, to address at all.  
• 
Bad Habits: These players have bad habits they need to unlearn – a difficult transition, at best.  
• 
Underrated/High Ceiling: Aspect of player’s game with high-end potential with room to improve.  

 
21 
 
For additional information on the details, refer to the glossary. 
 
 
Skill Category Subheadings  
 
The subheadings under each skill should be reasonably self-explanatory, but here’s a quick breakdown:  
 
• 
Star Caliber: Rivals the best in the game at his position.  
• 
Starter Caliber: Commensurate with a full-time starter at his position.  
• 
Committee Caliber: A baseline level of skill for a player to contribute productively to an offense.  
• 
Reserve Caliber: Lacking something to consistently be productive, but good enough to contribute.  
• 
Free Agent: Lacking the minimum skill to make a team if evaluated strictly by this single component.  
• 
Deficient: Skill set is so lacking that it must improve to earn consideration if judging strictly by this component.  
 
Weighted values are located at the bottom of each tier. Bonus points are 10 percent of the highest possible score. For

Weighted values are located at the bottom of each tier. Bonus points are 10 percent of the highest possible score. For 
example, if the highest possible weighted score for Separation is 9 points, the bonus allotment is 0.9 points. If a player’s 
performance in the separation category falls under “Reserve Caliber” he earns 3.6 points from the tier. If the player is noted 
as both an “easy fix” and “underrated-high ceiling,” the player will earn 1.8 bonus points.  
 
Accuracy Grades 
 
The RSP has expanded its charting of accuracy and incorporates accuracy percentage thresholds into its grading of the 
accuracy listed in the Skill Breakdowns:  
 
• 
Scripted and unscripted situations. 
• 
Throwing on and off platform. 
• 
Throwing from a stance and on the move. 
• 
Passes delivered to the same side of the field and the opposite hash.  
• 
The presence and absence of pressure.  
• 
Targets against man and zone coverage. 
 
Combinations of these criteria are matched with the zones and distance ranges of the field: 
 
Distances (From the quarterback to the receiver) 
 
• 
Short: 0-14 yards. 
• 
Intermediate: 15-28 yards. 
• 
Vertical: 29-42 yards. 
• 
Deep: Distances greater than 42 yards. 
 
Zones 
 
• 
Short sideline, flat, and middle of the field. 
• 
Intermediate sideline, flat, and middle of the field. 
• 
Vertical sideline, flat, and middle of the field. 
• 
Deep sideline, flat and middle of the field.

Platform Accuracy 
 
Accuracy is how close-to-target a quarterback can throw a pass. The skill requires good judgment, patience, poise, 
anticipation, and, in most cases, good throwing technique and arm strength. I evaluate these players on their short, 
intermediate, and deep accuracy, and their accuracy on the move.  
 
NFL-caliber accuracy is significantly more demanding than what is acceptable for a college quarterback. NFL offenses have a 
greater emphasis on timing routes. The expectation for “open” in the NFL is often a receiver in single coverage who, in the 
college game, would be considered well-covered (although this is changing with certain routes).  
 
In the NFL, it’s not just about getting the ball in the area of the receiver but placing the ball in a tight window away from the 
defender. Throwing the ball to an area where the receiver can make an adjustment to the pass in tight coverage—“throwing 
a receiver open”—has also become a common expectation.  
 
Arm strength—or velocity—might be the skill most overrated by the average fan. There are two components to arm 
strength: distance and velocity. As long as a quarterback can throw the ball 35-40 yards with strong accuracy and good 
velocity, he can produce at a high level in the NFL.  
Joe Burrow is a perfect example. There are some players who improved their arm strength after entering the league (Drew 
Brees, Matt Ryan and Tom Brady), and it’s becoming a more common occurrence with changes to grip, release point, and 
especially heightened attention to the legs and hips during releases. Even so, we have not seen a prospect transform his 
arm strength from below standard to star-caliber.

footwork of a rollout, he’s throwing off-platform. These are improvised forms of jump passes, throws off the back foot, or 
pass attempts where the quarterback alters the position of his body at an odd angle to deliver the ball. Many of these 
throws do possess techniques that generate the necessary velocity and trajectory on the ball, but they are not used as the 
desired ending point of drops or rollouts and the stances are less stable.

to the point of the reception.

There are several components to a quarterback’s delivery: drops, foot spacing, set-ups, and release mechanics (arm 
motion, incorporation of legs and hips during the release motion, and ball position). A quarterback with a sound delivery 
process can back pedal, create good depth from the line of scrimmage, set his feet, and release the ball so the trajectory of 
the ball is controlled, timely, and accurate. This is a fundamental part of the position.  
Consistent accuracy comes from consistent upper- and lower-body mechanics and building up muscle memory. If a 
quarterback lacks proper coordination and timing with his feet, his accuracy drops. A great way to think about accuracy is to 
consider the sport of boxing. Watch the movie Million Dollar Baby and pay close attention to the scene where the trainer is 
talking about footwork.

text:
ose attention to the scene where the trainer is 
talking about footwork.  
The casual boxing fan thinks about boxing as hitting with the hands, but the feet set up everything the hands do. This is 
also true with football. This is why Bill Walsh stressed footwork as a vital component of a quarterback’s game. It’s no 
coincidence that Tom Brady, who was not mobile, but extremely good at avoiding pressure in the pocket and then throwing 
an accurate pass, has a boxing background.  
Of course, a quarterback—like a boxer—must show good form with his upper body. As with boxing, a quarterback’s delivery 
should be compact and thrown with the body behind it, just like a punch, so it is delivered with a snap. The less compact a 
release is, the easier it is for the opponent to see what’s coming and react.  
Just as running backs who “run with their eyes” (processing information fast enough to physically react) have a great 
synchronization of what they see and how they move, quarterbacks have the same skill. Joe Montana’s footwork was among 
the best ever.  
He could change direction to throw the ball accurately from a variety of positions and do it fast enough to maintain the 
integrity of his timing routes. Aaron Rodgers’ skill at altering his drops in reaction to the defense is a phenomenal example 
of this synchronization. 
Key: Little to no change; Easy Fix; Hard Fix; Bad Habits; High Ceiling—can improve, or skill between tiers. The values at

 Release/Delivery 
The delivery is the process of throwing the football. It begins with the drop, continues with the setup, and finishes with the 
follow-through. The process should be efficient, compact, and versatile, and it should yield an easy-to-catch football.  
The best technicians often have more range to express their talent and keep their efforts inside the structure of a play. At 
the same time, there are successful quarterbacks—even Hall of Fame talents—whose mechanics are far from perfect. Think 
of delivery mechanics as a technique that even the best players continuously hone throughout their careers.

Decision-Making 
 
The most important part of quarterback play is sound decision-making. It involves understanding the offense’s goal and 
recognizing how the defense tries to stop it. This recognition occurs prior to the snap and in the earliest moments of the 
play.  
 
A good passer understands where all his receivers are supposed to be on the field and how to set up the opponent to create 
passing lanes. A successful decision maker has an aggressive mentality, and he forces the defense to account for all 
quadrants of the field on every play. But he also needs patience and wisdom not to force passes downfield.  
 
The very best quarterbacks can integrate both their physical skills (footwork, ball handling, arm, etc.) and conceptual 
understanding of the game with excellent timing and fluidity to successfully manipulate the defense. This involves a 
thorough grasp of the playbook, game situations, and the strengths and weaknesses of opponents and teammates.
