analysis:
**Rourke:**

* **Strengths:**  Good pocket presence, capable of extending plays outside the pocket, accurate on check-downs, sells routes effectively, manages the pocket clock well.  Shows ability to hit deep routes (corner route).
* **Opportunities:**  Further development of pre-snap reads beyond the first 1-2 options to avoid throwing the ball away under pressure.
* **NFL Player Comparison:**  A mobile quarterback with good accuracy on shorter throws, perhaps a comparison to a younger, less established version of a quarterback like Russell Wilson (in terms of mobility and pocket awareness) but without the same arm strength.


**Brosmer:**

* **Strengths:**  Excellent sideline-to-sideline reads, utilizes play-action effectively, accurate deep throws, particularly up the seam, targets receivers away from defender leverage (especially in the red zone), good at accounting for peripheral defenders on quick reads and adjusting positioning to create completions.
* **Opportunities:**  Needs to improve recognition of favorable leverage before throwing the ball away, should be more decisive on easy shallow reads instead of taking sacks (especially on 1st & 10), needs to improve accounting for peripheral defenders when targets are further downfield.
* **NFL Player Comparison:** A quarterback with pinpoint accuracy on intermediate and deep throws, similar to a player like Kirk Cousins (in terms of accuracy and decision-making on timing routes) but perhaps needs more improvisation ability and consistent decision making under pressure.  The comparison is less about mobility, and more about arm talent and decision making from the pocket.

Ball Handling 
 
There are two components to ball handling for quarterbacks: basic transactions (snaps and handoffs) and sleight of hand 
(play fakes and pump fakes). The first is required to play the position. The second is an elevated skill. Players that take 
pride in the details of their craft often excel with play and pump fakes.  
 
Some college offenses don’t place as much emphasis on these fakes. In some cases, players lack the hand size to execute 
them. Therefore, it’s not a hard and fast rule that elevated skill at ball handling is a surefire sign of craftsmanship for the 
position as a whole.

Ball Security 
 
Ball security used to be a part of ball handling but after years of observation, I’ve come to believe it should be separated 
from ball fakes. Ball security is the quarterback’s carriage of the ball as a passer in the pocket and a runner breaking the 
pocket.  
 
Quarterbacks should hold the ball chest high with both hands as they drop back, set up, scan the field, and maneuver away 
from pressure while maintaining a throwing-ready position.  
 
When breaking the pocket, they should tuck the ball high to their chest and with their elbow tight to their frame. They 
should use the boundary arm or the arm that’s working away from pursuit if and when there’s room for them to switch the 
ball away from traffic.

text:
s in the pocket. When 
he accelerates to break the pocket, the ball drops to his thighs and he waves the ball around as he runs—I wish I could spin 
it as a series of pump fakes—but it would be like telling you the moon landing was faked. Pursuit has forced fumbles 
because of Sanders’ lapses with ball security.  
 
Sanders has been a part of multiple snaps in the red zone where he wasn’t ready or the center had the wrong snap count—
both are Sanders’ responsibility as the leader of the unit. 
 
Jalen Milroe defaults to the right arm as a ball carrier, even when the play design is to the left side of the field. Until he 
encounters pursuit that he sees, Milroe’s security is loose and sometimes wide from his frame. When he encounters pursuit 
he can see, Milroe secures the ball high and tight to his chest and side. He can take contact to the ball and ball-carrying 
arm. 
 
When in the pocket and maneuvering it from pressure, Milroe keeps both hands on the ball. When he breaks the pocket, the 
ball can get wide, or he carries it like he’s running the triple option and he’s susceptible to strip sacks and chops from 
backside pursuit.  
 
 
 
Pocket Presence 
 
Cam Newton’s phenomenal rookie year had several contributing factors, but his poise was most prominent, allowing him to 
stand fast in the pocket and survey his receivers as defenders flew around him. Newton efficiently side-stepped pressure or 
moved up in the pocket while maintaining a throwing stance and mindset (eyes downfield). Unless a player comes along to 
blow the notion to smithereens, no quarterback can enjoy long-term success in the NFL until he learns how to command the 
pocket.  
 
A quarterback must feel where the pressure is coming from, know how to maneuver away while staying prepared to throw, 
and have the toughness to step into an oncoming defender to release an accurate throw. None of this involves speed, 
tackle-breaking, or elaborate jukes, spins, or cuts.

have the toughness to step into an oncoming defender to release an accurate throw. None of this involves speed, 
tackle-breaking, or elaborate jukes, spins, or cuts.  
 
Great ball-carrying skill can make for a fine weapon in the open field, but it doesn’t help a quarterback throw the ball. 
Michael Vick, Tim Tebow, and Eric Crouch all possessed great mobility, yet lacked the ability to maneuver in tight spaces 
while focusing on the structure of the play.  
 
Good pocket presence is one of the surest indicators of poise and a key fundamental for higher-level execution. In 20 years 
of studying players, I have not seen a quarterback who lacks fundamental pocket presence experience long-term success as 
a high-end starter. 
 
Pocket Presence encompasses two categories: Senses Press and Maneuvering-Accuracy.

There are also instances where Shough saw play-side edge pressure but didn’t accelerate the pace of his play. He took a hit 
trying to throw a check-down that he had time to deliver sooner or time to break the pocket and run.   
 
His pocket clock against edge pressure may also need work if he sensed the edge pressure. This appears to be the case 
based on his decision-making vs. pressure. If blindside edge pressure is coming from the same side as his initial reads 
downfield, he can spot it.  
 
He’s better at edge pressure on the play side. He senses it on time, reduces his shoulder, climbs, and flushes into a rollout.  
He has a better pocket clock in the red zone than he does in other places on the field, but has lapses there, too.

37 
Maneuver-Accuracy 
I’m seeking quarterbacks that can exhibit a repertoire of effective movement, plus the ability to reset and fire the ball with 
accuracy. These skills include climbing the pocket, sliding a step to the left or right, reducing the shoulder from the reach of 
a defender, spinning from pressure, ducking under contact or flushing to a side of the field.  
 
Retreating from pressure is also acceptable if it fits the context of the situation. The ability to buy time won’t matter if the 
quarterback can’t make good on that time. The more ways a quarterback can avoid pressure and deliver the ball with 
accuracy, the higher his grade.

(Maneuver-Accuracy) The Best: Jalen Milroe identifies interior pressure early in his drop and curtails his footwork to 
sidestep the defender. He reduces his shoulder from the defender’s reach and pulls through whatever contact the defender 
can make.  
 
Milroe executes a quick climb and sidestep of pressure to reset and fire from the pocket with at least catchable accuracy in 
the shallow range of the field. He has quiet feet: He doesn’t need a lot of movement to manipulate one side of the field and 
at the last moment, make a small adjustment of his frame to target the far side of the field and accurately.  
 
His vertical throws can sail on him in the same scenarios and his feet aren’t fully aligned with the target. At the same time, 
Milroe also completes vertical passes with placement among 2-3 defenders where the receiver is the only player who can 
earn the target.  
 
Milroe has an effective climb-and-flush combination to work into open space. He also delivers a quick spin and roll to his 
right from interior pressure. 
 
Cam Ward can wait for interior pressure to get within a step of him and he’ll spin and roll to his left. He’ll also side-step 
interior pressure. He can sidestep and then reverse field with a short climb and flush to his left and find an open man 
downfield who is working free in zone coverage.  
 
Ward routinely climbs the pocket and combines other maneuvers with it. He combines all of the maneuvers to create space.  
 
Ward will flush away from safety blitz and reach the open field. When pressure hasn’t compromised the pocket but he has 
spent 2-3 seconds in the pocket and no routes are coming open, Ward drifts deeper to set up opportunities to roll outside 
and buy more time while keeping his eyes downfield.

Ward has a penchant for drifting to the left edge or outside the pocket when it’s unnecessary. It closes off the field for him

38 
(Maneuver-Accuracy) Needs Improvement: Shough must learn that sidestepping edge pressure to the left and trying to 
power the football to the right on a deep post can lead to inaccurate placement and give a safety time to adjust his position 
and cut off the target. If he’s going to make these throws, he must lead the receiver away from the safety.  
 
Shough can be reactive to pressure that arrives fast and the result of the reactivity is that Shough doesn’t follow through 
with his feet during his release. It can impact his accuracy. 
 
 
 
Scrambling 
Scrambling can be an extension of pocket presence, but I believe it’s a different skill. A player that scrambles commits to 
buying time to throw the ball even if it means disrupting his teammates’ leverage advantages with blocking assignments.  
I’m seeking vision to juggle the tasks of avoiding pursuit while finding an open receiver. This requires various degrees of 
familiarity with his scheme and the coverage, communication with his receivers, creativity, power to pull through contact, 
and agility and short-area quickness to avoid it.

(Running) The Best: Milroe has the acceleration to work past box defenders quickly as he breaks the pocket. He also has 
the suddenness with pressure cuts to press a downfield safety and dip away from the defender late enough that the safety 
can’t change his angle of pursuit on time. He also throws in a pump fake with the dip that can freeze the defender.  
 
Milroe has the acceleration to get the short corner on box defenders and split linebackers and safeties. He can also turn the 
corner when working to the far-side of the formation. He can turn the corner on a short-field cornerback on a read-option 
carry and outrun the field.  
 
Milroe has excellent curvilinear bend and speed in the open field. He can undercut secondary defenders in pursuit, carving 
an S in the open field to work from one flat to the opposite boundary. He has a top speed of 22 mph.  
 
Milroe can press the line of scrimmage within a step and open his hips with the point of the toe so he can bounce outside. 
He only needs one step to transition downhill from a perimeter approach. He has a tight spin to get outside pursuit or work 
off contact. Milroe also has an excellent hip shift to work past a box defender in traffic.  
 
When finishing runs in the middle of the field, he’ll slide. He’s a big-play scat back in a quarterback’s role.  
 
(Running) Needs Improvement: He has the short-area quickness to outflank pursuit in traffic and he can come to a 
quick stop, but his re-start quickness is not notable. Sanders can run through glancing shots to his side from safeties and 
force them to wrap up. He’ll slide when possible.  
 
Sanders has enough speed to turn the corner on some linebackers, but he may have a rude awakening about his athletic 
ability and what he can get away with in the NFL. In the pros, Sanders may need time to recalibrate his college habits as a 
runner.   
 
(Running) The Worst: Kurtis Rourk

Jaxson Dart, Ole Miss: Dart’s accuracy wanes somewhere between 25-30 yards and beyond and becomes scattershot. 
He’s overthrowing, underthrowing, and behind and ahead of targets.  
 
The scary part for me is that Dart’s setup, stance, and release lack any significant flaws beyond that his feet need to be 
undisturbed and narrower to deliver with accuracy at a range of 30-45 yards. When forced to maneuver from pressure, 
Dart’s feet get too wide and it leads to inaccuracies. 
 
From this standpoint, Dart must develop a strong skill for climbing the pocket where his footwork is precise. This could give 
him a chance to overcome this specific symptom of his inaccuracies downfield.  
 
Dart’s pre-draft love feels more like a projection of what he can be than what his game currently is, but it’s not as bad of 
projection Zach Wilson’s. It’s closer to Drew Lock and J.J. McCarthy. If the work ethic is there, success could be imminent. If

43 
Rourke is an accurate thrower thanks to his clean footwork and compact and efficient release mechanics. He holds middle of 
the field defenders to one side of the field to buy room to target a route breaking from the opposite side of the field. Rourke 
does this well within the rhythm of his drops and the routes.  
 
He is confident targeting receivers in tight windows of coverage and has the placement to do so. Rourke is particularly 
skilled with placement in the vertical passing game and accounting for the peripheral defender peeling off his spot to assist 
with coverage. He can work through multiple reads, sidestep pressure, reset, and deliver the ball so if his receiver obeys the 
placement, the receiver can split defenders in coverage for additional yardage.  
 
Rourke is a smart quarterback with technical skill and promising conceptual knowledge that translates to the field. He’s also 
one of the toughest football players in this draft class. His scouting report will tell you why.

Projects  
Given the pains I’ve taken to explain why the NFL has a quarterback development problem, it’s difficult to devote a serious 
amount of time to potential projects. However, there is still a history of late-round picks and undrafted players developing 
into competent backups and starters.  
Or, you could argue, players more talented than their draft capital who were given the opportunity to surprise.  
There are also early-round players who should have been considered projects who needed more developmental time behind 
the scenes than their draft capital warranted but eventually figured it out, including Alex Smith, and Michael Vick, and 
perhaps, one day, Jordan Love. Here’s a brief list of players who I believe offer that brightest glimmer of hope. 
Will Howard, Ohio State: Howard has a good foundation with his drops, play fakes, pump fakes, and release mechanics. 
Only small tweaks are necessary for Howard to refine these parts of his game.  
 
Arm strength is an asset. He can stretch the field in the vertical game, and Howard has a good feel for when he can toss the 
ball and allow a wide-open vertical option to trot under it without getting too fine with placement.  
 
Howard’s mobility is also a strength of his game. When he abandons the pocket he has the acceleration to turn the corner 
on linebackers. Howard has the balance to bounce off glancing shots from defensive backs and pull through reaches from 
most defenders.  
 
As a decision maker, Howard’s game is a mixed bag but salvageable. If Howard can improve his leverage reads and know 
which defenders to keep track of during a play, he could become a competent reserve with the athletic upside to produce 
when called upon. If he can become an excellent game manager and quell his arrogance with his arm, he might have a shot 
to start.  
 
Quinn Ewers, Texas: Ewers’ game is at that line of demarcation between a player with a decent chance of developing into 
a start

text:
nds’ role is much different from Derrick Henry’s. DK Metcalf is a vastly different receiver than Cooper Kupp. 
Lamar Jackson might perform well in New England’s offense, but would you have asked Mac Jones to run Baltimore’s 
offense? Was Tom Brady a far worse quarterback than Steve Young because Young would have fared well in more varieties 
of systems because of his athletic ability?  
You can have fun debating the questions, but the point is that all the players mentioned above have value and a linear 
ranking isn’t an accurate portrayal of their value. I prefer tiers because in most cases, there are groups of players that are 
so close in skill that a tier comes closer to recognizing talent value.  
It shouldn’t matter to you whether Bryce Young, C.J. Stroud, and Anthony Richardson are Nos. 2, 3, and 4 on an analyst’s 
board; it’s more important to know if they’re all within the same tier.  
Three years from now, you may argue that Fields significantly out-performed the other two, but organizational fit, system 
fit, health, and surrounding talent are just four of several variables that don’t make a one-to-one comparison an accurate 
way of viewing talent. Nevertheless, I understand the desire for a linear order.  
The rankings in each chapter will also have headings that note the beginning of tiers where I would group these players. It 
satisfies my desire to dissuade readers from overreacting to a linear number (Why do you have [insert player’s name here] 
soooo lowwwww...) while giving you, the fantasy owner and draftnik, a starting range to shift your boards around based on 
your team needs and fit.  
 
 
 
Depth of Talent Score 
 
The RSP compiles points in these tiers and the ease-of-fix bonuses into a Depth of Talent Score. Here is the grading scale: 
 
 
• 
100-95 (Rare): Instant All-Pro upside; takes over games and changes teams. 
• 
90-94 (Franchise): Immediate production and leadership anchor. 
• 
85-89 (Starter): Starting immediately with large role a

00-95 (Rare): Instant All-Pro upside; takes over games and changes teams. 
• 
90-94 (Franchise): Immediate production and leadership anchor. 
• 
85-89 (Starter): Starting immediately with large role and learning on the go.  
• 
80-84 (Rotational Starter): Executes at a starter level in a role playing to their strengths.  
• 
75-79 (Contributor): Starter execution in a limited role; diminishing returns beyond that scope. 
• 
70-74 (Reserve): Contributor with limitations in scope and execution.  
• 
60-69 (Developmental): Special Teams, end of bench, and practice squad players. 
• 
0-59 (Street): Developmental talents with deficits in experience, technique, or athletic ability. 
 
The grades assigned to rookies are a portrait of their games based on their college performance and—depending on the 
nature of their flaws—a small-to-moderate projection of improvement. The grades given to rookies are not static; they are 
only a starting point of the player’s development.  
 
If a player with a contributor grade improves in 2-3 areas during training camp, his rookie year, or his first offseason, he 
could emerge as a talent 2-3 levels higher on the scale.  
 
While the players in the lowest four tiers have the greatest volume of issues, many of their problems are easy fixes. This 
can lead to rapid improvement.  
 
As a player’s talent climbs the grading scale, the volume of flaws declines, but the difficulty addressing existing flaws 
increases. 
 
The on-field impact of these gains also differs based on talent level. Players in the lower tiers will make the largest gains, 
but they are often less impactful than the smallest gains by a player in the highest tiers.

Injuries.

Scheme fit.

and fiscal factors listed above—that “decent” or “good” grade may not matter. 
 
I will list Depth of Talent Score for each player in the Rankings Profiles as well as the cheat sheet tables at the end of the 
chapter. 
 
 
 
Quarterback Prospect Rankings  
These rankings are a reflection of players with the greatest chance to make a positive impact if they see the field, 
regardless of future draft status, depth chart spot, or character. The rankings are based on talent, skill, scheme versatility 
and/or strong match to a specific offensive system. I didn’t have time to evaluate all of the draft eligible quarterbacks, but I 
will provide analysis of their work in the RSP Post-Draft if a player I did not cover is drafted.  
 
Pre-Draft Dynasty Landscape and Advice 
 
Perception shouldn’t matter as much as it does, but perception comprises much of what we call a player’s “draft capital.” 
The NFL is a classist society. Players with a higher draft capital earn more opportunities than those with a lower draft stock, 
and it generates unhealthy biases about each.  
 
Players with higher draft stocks earn more practice reps and chances to fail than players with low draft capital—or no draft 
capital at all. This generates an expectation that when early-round players make mistakes during practice or preseason 
games that they’ll eventually figure it out whereas late-round players who make fewer mistakes with fewer reps are simply 
not that good.  
 
This phenomenon of bias—the Hidden Advantage of Being a High NFL Draft Pick—is something that my fri

This is class of prospects where there is no Caleb Williams – player who I wrote last year had more in his toolbox to survive

The third quarterback on the RSP’s board lacks the physical upside of the first two but if he develops the work ethic and 
builds on his cognitive talents as a passer, he could emerge as a capable starter.  
 
The fourth quarterback might be the best long-term investment if you have the patience. He’ll likely be a low-cost 
investment, too.  
 
The gap between who processes the field quickly and confidently and/or manage the game effectively is narrow in point 
value, but what it takes to develop a productive approach can prove more difficult than anything with quarterbacking.  
Whoever from this group of players ranked 5th-9th on the board can close this narrow and complex space could become a 
valuable NFL starter.  
 
More than half try and fail. The leftovers might have journeyman potential.

Elevator Pitch: Cam Ward will earn Patrick Mahomes comparisons because he can buy time in and outside the pocket and he makes 
against-the-grain throws while on the move. Drew Lock and Zach Wilson earned these comparisons as well.  
 
It’s a superficial comparison. Ward’s game is closer in style to Mahomes’ trailer-park cousin, Johnny Manziel, except Ward’s game won’t be 
found on Trailer Park Boys TV.  
 
Ward’s game lives in one of few the apartment complexes in that high-end, suburban neighborhood. You know the type: Where the schools 
are good, and daddies offer to buy brand-new SUVs for their daughters as a bribe for taking the in-state government academic scholarship 
to a public school while steering clear of the expensive, out-of-state program. 
 
Ward’s game has seen the refined way of life through most of his friends, but he lives in the neighborhood with divorcees, cranky old people 
whose families got as far away from them as possible (often for good reason), and the kids who grow up there are considered the high-risk 
children at the school.  
 
Ward is an off-script, playground creator with enough technical and conceptual skills to develop into a prominent NFL starter. Miami and 
Washington State used Ward in systems that delivered a lot of quick-hitting RPOs and screens in the short passing game and resorted to 
four verticals – four receivers running go routes – and letting Ward buy time to find an open man.  
 
Ward has become at finding creative ways to get the ball out of his hand on quick-hitting plays and buying time and space on the long-
developing plays to help a target work open when forced off-script. It’s the points in between these two extremes of offense where Ward 
has shown enough to promise to become a productive NFL quarterback.

text:
Ward 
has shown enough to promise to become a productive NFL quarterback.  
 
This will depend on how well a team does to set the stage for Ward’s development and/or if Ward can survive the potential onslaught that 
usually happens with rookies in the NFL.  
 
As good as Ward can be off-script, he must tighten up his drop footwork, set ups, and his releases. Most of the work that’s necessary is with 
his lower body.  
 
Some teams may believe Ward’s arm mechanics require the most tinkering, but I would caution coaches to be careful about messing with it. 
Ward has a whip-like motion that’s quick, generates velocity, and his accuracy issues have more to do with his feet than his arm.  
 
Ward has the arm talent to start in the NFL. He can make most, if not all, of the throws from the pocket that NFL coaches want in their 
offense and use a variety of throwing platforms to do so.  
 
Ward manipulates defenders with well-executed ball fakes in the play-action game as well as pump fakes in and outside the pocket. The 
play-action game is where Ward exhibited the most cohesive and fluid aspects of drop footwork.  
 
When dropping from pistol and shotgun, Ward’s footwork is fragmented in pacing and fluidity of steps. It doesn’t look good, but it hasn’t 
killed his timing thus far. While that might prove the case when Ward transitions to the NFL, it’s likely that he’ll need to refine his footwork.  
 
If Ward doesn’t display clean, organized, and fluid drop footwork in game action this summer, it may be a compelling enough reason to 
keep Ward on the bench and give him time to develop the technique that will be the foundation for everything he does as a decision-maker 
and thrower in the passing game. Last year, Caleb Williams struggled for half of the season with the Bears because drop footwork was 
among the problems with this offense. There were plays where the Bears’ former offensive coordinator didn’t have prescribed footwork for 
the drop and Williams’ timing was off

Williams had better drop footwork coming out of school than Ward’s appears at this point. When coverage is as tight as it can be in the NFL 
and pressure reaches the pocket earlier, a quarterback must be efficient and precise. Sloppy footwork doesn’t create a foundation for 
efficient and precise play.  
 
Ward’s decision-making has high points. From a clean pocket, he can split defenders with downfield throws based on good reads of 
leverage. He can deliver with touch, velocity, and throw the moon ball in the deep game so his receivers can win targets with their athletic 
ability.  
 
Ward is often aware of defenders in the periphery of his intended targets and knows when that defender is in too good of position for Ward 
to target the route. He has lapses with this awareness and it unfortunately happens in the most compressed region of the field where the 
mistakes have more gravity – the red zone.  
 
Ward’s ability to buy time, layer targets over the defense, split coverage, and notice peripheral defenders raises his confidence in his ability 
to bleed every bit of opportunity from a play. When he exhausts his options, he’ll throw the ball away. However, he takes sizable risks 
before doing so – reversing field, backing away from pressure, and attempting across-the-body throws.

analysis:
**Ward:**

**Strengths:**

* **Quick release and RPO execution:**  Excels at getting the ball out quickly on RPOs (Run-Pass Options), even under pressure.  He's creative with his release to maintain accuracy.
* **Effective play-fakes:**  Sells play-fakes convincingly, utilizing strong timing, extension, and duration.  He even incorporates subtle hints towards the runner.
* **Manipulative pump fakes:** Uses shoulder fakes, ball flashes, and small pitch/shovel fakes to manipulate the secondary and freeze defenders.  He demonstrates a variety of pump fake styles.
* **Ball security (in some situations):**  Maintains good ball security when taking contact to the chest.


**Opportunities/Weaknesses:**

* **Inconsistent drops:**  Dropbacks are inconsistent in terms of pace, width, and stance, particularly from the pistol or shotgun formation.  Needs improvement for a timing-based passing game.  His drops were more consistent under center.
* **Ball security (in other situations):** Vulnerable to hits near the elbow when breaking the pocket to his left, as he doesn’t switch the ball to his boundary-side arm.

Release: Ward can deliver the ball with three-quarter motion while moving to his left. He has a side-arm motion with RPOs. Ward is 
effective throwing off his back foot in the shallow range of the field.  
Ward sets his feet quickly on RPOs and quick targets outside. The midline of his back foot and the toe of his front foot are aligned with the 
target. He bounces on his toes in his stance and when he slides a step laterally, his bouncing can creep into his throwing motion and that 
can be disruptive.  
Earlier in the season, I noticed with specific throws that Ward’s cleats didn’t stay in the ground as he’s throwing the ball. Keeping his cleats 
in the ground as he throws the ball can enhance his velocity and placement. He has throws where his front foot takes an added stutter step. 
This is a technique known as a Foot Pop which helps create stability by decelerating their pelvis and torso after maximizing their rotation. 
This is typically done when throwing to their left or moving forward.

analysis:
**Quarterback: Ward**

**Strengths:**

* **Arm Strength and Accuracy:** Possesses strong arm talent, evidenced by pinpoint deep throws (63-65 yards) and accurate throws to the sideline (27 yards).  Shows good touch on deep throws ("moon balls").
* **Mobility:**  Displays the ability to extend plays by breaking the pocket and throwing effectively on the run, even off his back foot.  Uses a pump fake effectively to freeze defenders.
* **Quick Release (situational):**  Sets his feet quickly on RPOs and short routes, leading to efficient throws.

**Opportunities for Improvement:**

* **Footwork and Balance:** Inconsistent footwork can disrupt his throwing motion, leading to inaccuracy.  Needs to keep his cleats in the ground during throws to improve velocity and placement.  Wide stance contributes to high throws.  Occasional stutter step ("Foot Pop") needs refinement for better consistency.
* **Release Mechanics:** Can improve upper-body release mechanics.  Bringing the ball down to his waist before the throw is inefficient and could lead to improved consistency and velocity.
* **Consistency:** While showcasing impressive throws, needs to improve consistency in his mechanics to eliminate high throws and sailed passes.


**NFL Player Comparisons:**  Difficult to make a precise comparison without more data on his overall game (decision-making under pressure, leadership, etc.). However, his arm strength and mobility suggest a potential comparison to quarterbacks like **Josh Allen** (strong arm, mobile, but inconsistent at times early in career) or, with improved consistency, perhaps a more accurate comparison to a younger **Patrick Mahomes** (exceptional arm talent and improvisational skills).  However, these are broad comparisons and he has significant work to do to reach their level.

Off-Platform Accuracy: Ward has good enough feet and athletic ability to deliver on platform – even with jump passes and 
throws on the move. I didn’t see him throw off-platform but once when he wasn’t under pressure.  
Opposite-Hash Accuracy: He has pinpoint accuracy at 25 yards from the release point to the opposite boundary.  
Mobile Accuracy: Ward has good short-range accuracy on the move. His intermediate-range accuracy is catchable but not often 
pinpoint. His vertical-range accuracy is competent.  
Decision-Making: When on-script without pressure as an issue, Ward can split the secondary and even a tight split of linebackers 
or safeties to thread the needle to a receiver downfield.   
Ward displays and awareness of defenders on the periphery of where he’s targeting his receivers. More often, he displays 
awareness of defenders who can cut off a target and moves away from that read. When he has lapses, he isn’t considering a route 
running near the targeted route and the defender having an easy position to peel off his receiver to attack the ball on the other. 
This has resulted in an end-zone interception and a dropped interception in the red-zone.  
Ward will work across the field with 2-3 progressions and then work to the opposite field for the check-down.  
Sense Pressure: Ward identifies post-snap safety pressure early in the play. He can scan the width of the field and anticipate when the 
pocket is about to break down and begin moving to buy more time as a thrower.  
Ward also spots interior pressure from two levels within the pocket and incrementally works his way outside with a roll. He can also shed 
the defender and incrementally climb in the pocket.

analysis:
**Summary of Quarterback Ward:**

**Strengths:**

* **Arm Strength and Accuracy:** Possesses a strong arm capable of delivering deep throws with pinpoint accuracy, particularly on post routes and fades.  Shows good accuracy on short and intermediate routes, even on the move.  Excellent opposite-hash accuracy.
* **Mobility and Pocket Presence:**  Displays good athleticism and ability to extend plays. Effectively moves within the pocket to avoid pressure, showing awareness of both interior and safety blitzes.  Can escape the pocket and maintain accuracy on shorter throws.
* **Decision-Making (under limited pressure):**  When not under duress, demonstrates excellent decision-making, showcasing the ability to thread the needle to receivers downfield, even through tight windows.  Displays awareness of defensive positioning.  Works through progressions effectively.


**Opportunities/Weaknesses:**

* **Off-Platform Accuracy:** While possessing good athleticism, off-platform throws are infrequent and less consistently accurate.
* **Intermediate and Deep Accuracy under Pressure:** Intermediate and deep accuracy diminishes under pressure. This leads to missed opportunities and potential turnovers.
* **Decision-Making Under Pressure:**  While he identifies pressure well, his decision-making suffers under duress.  He's prone to overlooking potential defensive disruptions resulting in interceptions or near interceptions.
* **Overall Consistency:** Needs to improve overall consistency in accuracy and decision-making, especially when facing pressure.

**NFL Player Comparisons:**

Based on the provided scouting report, Ward's skillset draws comparisons to quarterbacks who combine arm talent with mobility, but have some inconsistencies to refine:

* **High-End Potential:**  A young Russell Wilson or a more accurate Josh Allen, both known for their arm talent and escapability, but also their early-career inconsistency.
* **More Realistic Comparison:**  A player like Justin Fields (Bears), who has the physical tools and mobility but needs to improve his decision-making and accuracy under pressure.  His progression through reads and consistency in throws is still developing, similar to Ward's profile.

Maneuvering From Pressure Ward will flush away from safety blitz and reach the open field. When pressure hasn’t compromised the 
pocket but he has spent 2-3 seconds in the pocket and no routes are coming open, Ward drifts deeper to set up opportunities to roll outside 
and buy more time while keeping his eyes downfield. 
Ward has a penchant for drifting to the left edge or outside the pocket when it’s unnecessary. It closes off the field for him to make plays. 
The drifting has forced Ward to throw the ball away when he at least had potential check-downs if he remained in the pocket.  
Ward feels edge pressure to his throwing side and executes a short hitch to climb and throw in rhythm. He also can flush quickly from edge 
pressure that gets around the corner and behind him.  
Ward can wait for interior pressure to get within a step of him and he’ll spin and roll to his left. He’ll also side-step interior pressure. He can 
sidestep and then reverse field with a short climb and flush to his left and find an open man downfield who is working free in zone coverage.  
Ward routinely climbs the pocket and combines other maneuvers with it. He combines all of the maneuvers to create space.  
Accuracy (Pressure) 
On-Platform Accuracy: Ward has starter-caliber accuracy with most short and intermediate throws and he gives receivers a 
chance to make the play even when he’s not pinpoint accurate.  
His vertical accuracy is more hit-or-miss at the boundary, but he gives receivers more of a chance in the middle of the field when 
he’s not perfect with his placement.  
Off-Platform Accuracy: Ward has good enough feet and athletic ability to deliver on platform – even with jump passes and 
throws on the move. When he’s forced to throw off-platform while under pressure, the accuracy is competent in the shallow zones 
but hit-or-miss beyond that.

analysis:
**Quarterback: Ward**

**Strengths:**

* **Excellent pocket mobility and manipulation:** Ward displays a diverse skillset in navigating the pocket, including incremental movement, rollouts, climbs, spins, sidesteps, and flushes. He effectively uses these maneuvers to create throwing lanes and extend plays.  He's adept at avoiding both edge and interior pressure.
* **Good accuracy on short and intermediate throws:**  Ward possesses starter-level accuracy on most short to intermediate routes, consistently giving his receivers a chance to make plays.
* **Competent off-platform accuracy:**  He maintains decent accuracy even when throwing on the move or under pressure, particularly in shorter passing zones.
* **Athleticism:** His athleticism allows him to make plays both inside and outside the pocket.


**Opportunities/Weaknesses:**

* **Unnecessary drifting:** A tendency to drift unnecessarily to the left edge of the pocket limits his field vision and forces throws away when check-downs might have been available.
* **Inconsistent deep accuracy:** His deep ball accuracy, especially to the boundary, is less reliable than his short to intermediate throws.
* **Off-platform accuracy beyond shallow zones:** While his off-platform accuracy is competent in shorter ranges, it becomes less consistent on deeper throws made under pressure.


**NFL Player Comparisons:**

Based on the description, Ward's skillset resembles a blend of quarterbacks with good mobility and pocket presence but varying degrees of deep accuracy.  He could be compared to a more athletic version of a quarterback like **Russell Wilson** (in terms of pocket manipulation and improvisation) but with a potentially less consistent deep ball than Wilson in his prime, or perhaps a less accurate but more mobile **Kirk Cousins**.  The inconsistent deep accuracy prevents a comparison to truly elite mobile quarterbacks like Patrick Mahomes or Lamar Jackson.  A more apt comparison might be to a quarterback like **Justin Fields**, who exhibits impressive athleticism but is still developing deep ball consistency.

Mobile Accuracy: Ward can deliver the ball 20 yards to his right while moving to his left and with a three-quarter motion as 
pressure is bearing down from backside pursuit. He can deliver the ball 37 yards from the release on the move to his left.  
Decision-Making: Ward manipulates the secondary outside the pocket with a shoulder fake and directs receivers to work outside-
on as Ward reaches the flat as a scrambler. He finds the open zone.  
If Ward has exhausted his options even after he has bought extra time for his receivers to work open, Ward will throw the ball 
away.  
Ward attempts throws across his body on the move to his left with a defender bearing down that are high risk for the black zone 
and really, for any part of the field. There are examples of wide-open targets where Ward makes the athletic play and it’s a sound 
decision. He must eliminate the targets that are riskier.   
He can sidestep and then reverse field with a short climb and flush to his left and find an open man downfield who is working free 
in zone coverage. Ward can layer the ball over defenders in the red zone.  
When pressured, Ward will check-down when forced to the side of the field where there’s an outlet.  
He must be wiser about when to throw the ball away in situations where his offense is backed up and the defense has thwarted the 
quick-hitting play. When Ward is inside scoring range – field goal or touchdown – he tries too hard to make a play with the time he 
buys and it leads to sacks he could have easily avoided
analysis:
**Summary of Quarterback Ward:**

**Strengths:**

* **Mobility and Accuracy on the Move:**  Ward excels at throwing accurately on the move, particularly to shorter ranges (within 10 yards) and even while under pressure. He can make impressive throws while changing directions and extending plays.  He displays the ability to layer throws over defenders in the red zone.
* **Decision-Making (with caveats):** He shows good instincts in manipulating defenses outside the pocket, finding open receivers, and checking down when necessary.  He's generally willing to throw the ball away to avoid sacks.
* **Opposite Hash Accuracy (short range):**  Accurate on short throws to the opposite hash.


**Opportunities for Improvement:**

* **Accuracy on Deep Throws Off-Platform:** While competent on short throws under pressure, his accuracy drops significantly on longer throws made off-platform.
* **Decision-Making Under Pressure (Deep Throws):**  He needs to improve risk assessment on throws across his body under pressure and in situations where a sack would be preferable to a turnover.  He attempts too many high-risk plays when inside scoring range, leading to unnecessary sacks.
* **Throwing Away the Ball:** Needs better judgment on when to throw the ball away, particularly when backed up and facing a strong defense that has disrupted quick plays.
* **Opposite Hash Accuracy (long range):**  Needs to improve accuracy on long throws to the opposite hash.  Currently this is mostly accomplished with movement to the same side or middle of the field.


**NFL Player Comparisons:**

Finding a precise comparison is difficult due to the mixed bag of strengths and weaknesses, but elements of his game evoke a few different players:

* **Early-career Russell Wilson:**  Shares the mobility and ability to extend plays, making throws on the run.  However, Wilson's deep ball accuracy is considerably better.
* **Lamar Jackson (with caveats):**  Similar athleticism and improvisational skills, but Jackson generally has better accuracy and a stronger arm.  The comparison is mainly based on athleticism and extending plays.
* **Less polished version of Josh Allen:** Allen also struggles sometimes with accuracy and decision-making, but has a much stronger arm and more consistent deep ball accuracy than Ward demonstrates.

Ward's development will hinge on improving his decision-making under pressure and refining his accuracy on longer throws, particularly when off-platform. His athleticism gives him a high ceiling, but consistency needs improvement to reach his potential.

generate big-play rushes. Ward gets his feet high to avoid reaches from backside pursuit. His stiff arm has the timing and placement to 
ward off reaches from defensive lineman and force them to the ground.  
Ward has the agility to make defenders miss in the open field. He can transition downhill from a perimeter track with two small steps and 
get inside the shot of a force defender. Ward does not slide and he has opportunities to do so and avoid punishment.  
Durability: No significant injuries that cost Ward playing time.

analysis:
**Jake Ward - Quarterback Summary**

**Strengths:**

* **Quickness and Scrambling Ability:** Ward possesses exceptional quickness, allowing him to escape the pocket, buy time, and make plays outside the structure of the play.  He can avoid pressure and effectively reset his throwing platform.  His agility enables him to make defenders miss in the open field.
* **Running Ability:**  A capable runner, Ward can move the chains and even generate big plays on the ground. His stiff arm is effective at warding off defenders.
* **Durability:**  He has a strong injury history, having avoided significant setbacks impacting playing time.


**Opportunities:**

* **Improved Pocket Presence:** Ward needs to refine his tendency to drift unnecessarily out of the pocket, leading to missed opportunities for check-downs and throws.  He should focus on staying in the pocket more consistently when not under immediate pressure.
* **Decision-Making in the Red Zone:**  Ward needs to avoid forcing plays inside the scoring zone, leading to sacks that could be avoided by more conservative play calling.

**Weaknesses:**

* **Unnecessary Pocket Movement:**  A tendency to drift left out of the pocket, even when not under immediate pressure, limits his options.
* **Red Zone Decision-Making:**  A tendency to force plays inside the scoring zone resulting in sacks.
* **Sliding:**  Doesn't slide to avoid unnecessary hits.


**NFL Player Comparisons:**

The provided text doesn't offer a direct NFL comparison. However, based on his skillset (mobile quarterback with a need to improve pocket awareness and decision-making), a potential comparison could be a young, athletic quarterback who needed time to develop pocket presence, such as a less accurate, earlier version of **Josh Allen** (before his accuracy improvements) or a more mobile **Lamar Jackson** (but with a need to work on consistency within the pocket).  The comparison is not exact, as those players ultimately possessed higher ceiling potential, but the developmental arc might be similar.

in your fantasy drafts – where a small layer of information catches our eye and everything clicks for us. Look beyond that Hollywood 
moment and you’ll see years of experience that becomes ingrained enough for us so that the imprinted information registers in our 
subconscious just before our conscious mind gathers the rest of the story.

analysis:
**Jalen Milroe**

**Strengths:**

* **Exceptional Mobility:**  A highly proficient mover in the pocket, able to climb, spin, sidestep, and extend plays effectively without disrupting his team's protection or routes.  Excellent acceleration and agility as a runner, capable of making big plays with the ball.  Knows how to slide to protect himself.
* **Compact Release:** Possesses one of the most compact and quick releases among quarterbacks in his draft class, comparable to Dan Marino's.
* **Good Decision-Maker:** Makes decisions characteristic of established NFL starters, rather than a rookie prone to hero-ball plays.  Shows maturity in handling the pre-draft process.
* **Pocket Management:**  Excellent at managing the pocket and extending plays.


**Opportunities:**

* **Develop Touch:** Needs to improve accuracy on passes requiring touch and arc, particularly on corner fades and throws into tight coverage.  Currently prone to overshooting targets.
* **Acclimate to NFL:**  Needs to adapt to the complexities of NFL offenses (larger playbooks) and defenses (more sophisticated schemes and veteran players).


**NFL Player Comparison:** Jalen Hurts (but potentially a better runner, pocket manager, and game manager;  the comparison hinges on Milroe's yet-to-be-proven work ethic and dedication).

thrower.  
His release is so compact that Milroe can deliver in tight pockets with an even more truncated motion or a three-quarter release.

analysis:
This text analyzes the quarterbacking skills of Jalen Milroe, focusing primarily on his throwing mechanics and play-faking abilities.  Let's summarize:

**Jalen Milroe:**

**Strengths:**

* **Exceptional Release:** Milroe possesses incredibly compact and efficient upper-body mechanics, comparable to Dan Marino's. His straight-back arm motion and lower-body torque allow for powerful throws even in tight pockets. He can adjust his release to a three-quarter motion when needed.
* **Play-Faking:**  He demonstrates good detail and timing in his read fakes, effectively using the runner as an initial blocker.  He shows variety in his fakes, though execution could be refined for better deception.  He uses pump fakes effectively to manipulate defenders and create opportunities.

**Opportunities for Improvement:**

* **Play-Fake Nuance:** While his play-faking is good, adding more subtlety and deception would significantly enhance its effectiveness.
* **Lower Body Mechanics:** His lower body mechanics need refinement to improve throw placement and accuracy, particularly on certain throws.  The text suggests his leg positioning needs adjustment.
* **Pump Fake Consistency:**  While he uses pump fakes well, he doesn't employ them frequently, possibly due to his hand size limiting the effectiveness of a larger, more forceful pump.

**NFL Player Comparison:**

The most striking comparison is to **Dan Marino**, specifically regarding his remarkably compact and efficient throwing motion.  The text explicitly draws this parallel, highlighting the similarity in upper body mechanics.  However, it's important to note this is only one aspect of his game, and overall comparison requires considering his other skills and play style.  A complete comparison would be premature without analyzing other areas of his game.

analysis:
**Jalen Milroe:**

**Strengths:**

* **Strong Arm:** Possesses the arm strength to make throws across the field, including deep shots (up to 60 yards with catchable accuracy).  He can consistently hit targets at 40-48 yards to the opposite hash.
* **Accuracy on Platform:** Shows excellent accuracy when throwing from a stable base, especially in shorter and intermediate ranges. He's adept at layering throws to avoid coverage.  Pinpoint accuracy to the near-side flat at 58 yards.
* **Mobility & Accuracy on the Move:** Maintains accuracy while throwing on the run, showcasing pinpoint accuracy in short areas and catchable accuracy at intermediate, vertical, and deep ranges.
* **Good Decision Making (with room for improvement):**  Shows potential in reading defenses and making quick decisions in the three-step drop.


**Opportunities/Weaknesses:**

* **Touch and Ball Placement:** Needs to improve touch, especially on fade routes and throws requiring more air under the ball.  Frequently overshoots targets, even when attempting to add air. His fade routes are too flat, giving defenders a chance to intercept.  Needs work on throws into Cover 2 zones and back-shoulder throws.
* **Lower Body Mechanics:**  Needs improvement in his lower body mechanics to improve accuracy and ball placement.
* **Decision Making Consistency:** While showing promise, he could hold his eyes on the initial read for slightly longer to improve his decision-making process.


**NFL Player Comparisons:**

A direct comparison is difficult without more information, but based on the strengths and weaknesses, he could be compared to a mobile quarterback with a strong arm who needs refinement in their accuracy and touch.  Potentially a young version of **Lamar Jackson** (strong arm, mobile, but needs refinement in accuracy and decision-making), but also shows elements of **Josh Allen** (strong arm, but needs work on consistency and touch).  The comparison is very early-stage though.  More data would be needed to narrow it down.

analysis:
**Jalen Milroe:**

**Strengths:**

* **Arm Strength & Accuracy:** Possesses the arm talent to make throws at all levels (intermediate, vertical, deep).  Shows excellent placement, particularly on aggressive seam throws.
* **Pre-Snap Read & Anticipation:**  Excellent at identifying pre-snap pressure and coverage weaknesses, targeting the likely open receiver as his first read.  He understands leverage and uses it to his advantage.
* **Pocket Awareness & Mobility:**  Displays good awareness of pressure (both pre- and post-snap) from all areas, adept at maneuvering within the pocket to avoid pressure and create throwing lanes. He shows the ability to climb the pocket effectively.


**Opportunities for Improvement:**

* **Post-Snap Reads & Awareness:**  Struggles to consistently identify ancillary coverage (shallow flat defenders, boundary defenders undercutting routes), sometimes leading to missed opportunities or inaccurate throws. Needs to improve his ability to assess the entire field post-snap, especially on deeper crossing routes.
* **Decision-Making Under Pressure:**  While aggressive, he occasionally hesitates or makes overly cautious decisions (e.g., pulling down the ball on a seemingly open vertical route due to concerns about a deep safety).  He needs to trust his reads and make quicker, more decisive throws.


**NFL Player Comparison:**  A potential comparison could be **Josh Allen** (strong arm, mobile, aggressive but prone to occasional mistakes).  However, it’s important to note that Milroe is still developing and this comparison is based on a limited sample of his play.  Another, less flashy, but potentially more accurate comparison might be **Lamar Jackson** before he refined his decision-making process in the NFL, highlighting both the strong points and weaknesses in his skillset.

analysis:
**Jalen Milroe:**

**Strengths:**

* **Exceptional mobility and escapability:**  Milroe excels at evading pressure, utilizing quick climbs, sidesteps, spins, and rollouts to extend plays and create throwing lanes. He shows a knack for manipulating the pocket with minimal footwork.
* **Accuracy under pressure:**  He demonstrates impressive accuracy on short and intermediate routes even while facing significant pressure, including throws off his back foot and from awkward positions.  He displays pinpoint accuracy on throws up to 48 yards.  He also shows an understanding of adjusting the throw's trajectory to ensure catchability under pressure.
* **Strong arm:** Capable of making accurate vertical throws, even into tight windows with multiple defenders.


**Opportunities/Weaknesses:**

* **Consistency on vertical throws:** While capable of deep accuracy, his vertical throws can sometimes sail, especially when his feet aren't properly aligned with the target after climbing the pocket.  Improved footwork consistency is key.
* **On-platform accuracy on deep throws:**  His vertical throws under pressure, particularly to the middle of the field, need more consistent accuracy.  Setting his feet better after climbing the pocket should help.


**NFL Player Comparisons:**

Due to his strong arm, mobility, and ability to make plays outside the pocket, Milroe could be compared to quarterbacks like:

* **Lamar Jackson (Baltimore Ravens):**  Both possess exceptional athleticism and the ability to extend plays with their legs.  However, Jackson's passing consistency is currently ahead of Milroe's.
* **Josh Allen (Buffalo Bills):**  Both have strong arms and can make difficult throws. Allen's size is a difference, but both thrive on improvisation.  Allen currently exhibits better overall accuracy and consistency.

The comparison is less about a direct parallel and more about a stylistic similarity:  a mobile quarterback with a strong arm who can make plays outside the structure of the play.  Milroe's development will determine which end of the spectrum – Jackson or Allen – he more closely resembles.

analysis:
**Jalen Milroe - Quarterback Summary**

**Strengths:**

* **Exceptional Accuracy on the Move:**  Milroe displays remarkable accuracy throwing deep (50+ yards) while both rolling out and on the run, including pinpoint back-shoulder throws.  His accuracy extends to the opposite hash at significant distances even under duress.
* **Quick Decision-Making Under Pressure:** He efficiently processes reads (2-3) and makes accurate throws even with pressure in his face, demonstrating good pocket awareness and maneuverability.  He shows a strong understanding of game situations, prioritizing time over yardage when appropriate (e.g., two-minute drills).
* **Advanced Manipulation of Defenders:** Milroe utilizes his eyes to manipulate defenders, creating throwing windows by moving linebackers with his gaze. He effectively uses a stiff arm to protect himself while throwing the ball away under pressure.
* **Solid Scrambling Ability:** He effectively avoids pressure, buying time in and out of the pocket, and extending plays with his legs.  He shows the ability to break free from multiple defenders.

**Opportunities for Improvement:**

* **Ball Security in Extended Plays:** While infrequent, he occasionally holds onto the ball too long after escaping the pocket, creating unnecessary risks in the "black zone" (likely referring to the area near the end zone). This needs monitoring.


**NFL Player Comparisons:**

Milroe's skillset blends elements of several NFL quarterbacks. His strong arm and accuracy on the move are reminiscent of **Josh Allen** or **Lamar Jackson**. His ability to make quick decisions under pressure and manipulate defenders echoes traits seen in quarterbacks like **Patrick Mahomes**.  However, his need to refine ball security in extended plays suggests he needs to avoid becoming a turnover-prone player like some mobile quarterbacks can be.  His overall game perhaps most closely resembles a less refined, but potentially equally powerful, version of **Justin Fields**.

Milroe can slide outside interior pressure but make the quick stop and climb so he remains inside the pocket.  
Running: Milroe has the acceleration to work past box defenders quickly as he breaks the pocket. He also has the suddenness with 
pressure cuts to press a downfield safety and dip away from the defender late enough that the safety can’t change his angle of pursuit on 
time. He also throws in a pump fake with the dip that can freeze the defender.  
Milroe has the acceleration to get the short corner on box defenders and split linebackers and safeties. He can also turn the corner when 
working to the far-side of the formation. He can turn the corner on a short-field cornerback on a read-option carry and outrun the field.  
Milroe has excellent curvilinear bend and speed in the open field. He can undercut secondary defenders in pursuit, carving an S in the open 
field to work from one flat to the opposite boundary. He has a top speed of 21 mph.  
Milroe can press the line of scrimmage within a step and open his hips with the point of the toe so he can bounce outside. He only needs 
one step to transition downhill from a perimeter approach. He has a tight spin to get outside pursuit or work off contact. Milroe also has an 
excellent hip shift to work past a box defender in traffic.  
When finishing runs in the middle of the field, he’ll slide.  
Durability: No significant injuries.

analysis:
**Shedeur Sanders**

* **Strengths:** Excellent decision-maker, strong anticipation on quick game, well-defined short drops and good release, capable of attacking vertically and in the middle of the field with timing throws, excels at quick-hitting short routes and slow-developing downfield routes, promising play-action game.  He's a distributor at his best, but can create when needed.

* **Opportunities:**  Further development of his vertical passing game and ability to consistently perform in the deep middle.  Improving his athleticism to escape pressure and extend plays could elevate his game.

* **NFL Player Comparisons:** Geno Smith and Tua Tagovailoa.  This comparison highlights his ability as a distributor and his potential to succeed in a system that leverages his quick release and accuracy.  While he has the arm talent for vertical throws, he’s not compared to a hyper-athletic, strong-armed QB.

Sanders is a patient passer with enough pocket skills to buy time and create both on- and off-script. He’s not a dynamic mover in the Josh 
Allen-Jalen Hurts-Lamar Jackson archetype.  
Think Geno Smith and Baker Mayfield as the archetypical wheelhouse for Sanders as an athlete. Smith and Mayfield needed time to 
calibrate their athletic limits in the NFL. Expect Sanders to enter the league with some overconfidence in his athletic traits as well.  
Still, Sanders has shown promise as a player who can make adjustments. He has done this well when opposing coverage has gotten the 
better of him. The following week, if not the following half of the same game, Sanders often learns his lesson and makes a wiser decision 
with the same disguise or coverage look.  
Pre-snap, Sanders will identify the cushion of a defender in a two-man route combination and make the efficient drop and throw to the open 
man at the boundary and short out-breaking routes. With deep vertical routes in the middle of the field, he doesn’t identify the favorable 
leverage as quickly or accurately and this can lead him to abandon the pocket or check-down.  
Sanders is not as proficient with quick-game concepts where he must read sideline to sideline. He can be faster with identifying where to go 
on same-side concepts like double slants.   
Sanders is also prone to targeting intermediate routes breaking back to him at the boundary when there’s a defender squatting on the route 
over the top. Sanders does not understand the defender has the leverage advantage, especially when throwing from the far hash.

analysis:
**Quarterback: [Name not provided in text, referred to as "Sanders"]**

**Strengths:**

* **Patient passer with pocket presence:**  Sanders displays good pocket skills, buying time and creating plays both within and outside the designed structure.  He's adept at utilizing play-action.
* **Adaptability and learning:** Shows a capacity to learn from mistakes, adjusting his approach to coverages and defensive schemes from play to play or even half to half.
* **Efficient short and intermediate routes:**  Excels at reading pre-snap coverage and making quick, accurate throws to open receivers on short and intermediate routes, particularly those working across the field and to the boundary.  He's effective with slow-developing downfield routes.

**Opportunities/Weaknesses:**

* **Deep ball accuracy and decision-making:**  Struggles with identifying favorable leverage on deep vertical routes, sometimes leading to poor decisions (abandoning the pocket or checking down prematurely).  He needs to improve his deep ball accuracy and reads on these plays.
* **Quick-game reads:**  Needs to improve his processing speed and decision-making on quick-game concepts that require sideline-to-sideline reads.  He can be faster identifying targets on same-side concepts.
* **Intermediate route recognition:** Prone to targeting intermediate routes with defenders in advantageous positions, particularly from the far hash. He needs to better recognize leverage and avoid risky throws in these situations.
* **Overconfidence in athleticism:**  Expected to enter the league with some overconfidence in his athletic abilities, needing time to calibrate his limits as he develops.

**NFL Player Comparisons:**

* **Geno Smith and Baker Mayfield:** The text explicitly compares Sanders to these quarterbacks, suggesting a similar trajectory. Both Smith and Mayfield took time to develop and refine their skills in the NFL.  This comparison emphasizes a need for patience and coaching in Sanders' development.  The comparison highlights a potential for late-career success, but also acknowledges initial inconsistencies.

over the top. Sanders does not understand the defender has the leverage advantage, especially when throwing from the far hash.  
Compounding the problem, Sanders takes the risk with these routes in his team’s red zone. Black-zone decision-making, especially early in 
contests, should be far more conservative and minimize risk.  
He must mature as a game-manager. Some of his behavior may be the influence of his role as one of the few offensive leaders at Colorado. 
This is a common dynamic for college quarterback that must be tempered in the NFL.  
Sanders will throw the ball away if interior pressure reaches the pocket quickly or the pocket is so compressed that he can’t move away 
from the read that isn’t open. He must learn to throw the ball away earlier when on designed sprints. He lacks high-end mobility and he 
must trust his eyes more and his legs less or he’ll look like early-career Mayfield and Smith.  
Sanders holds one side of the field to set up a throw to the opposite flat and will stand in against interior pressure to execute. I don’t see 
manipulation of defenders in the middle of the field. This is why his ability to win in the middle of the field often has some projection to the 
analysis.  
I really don’t want to see Sanders thrust into a starting role immediately. If the team is good enough, especially along the offensive line, 
and there’s a strong ground component that sets up longer-developing plays with time to execute, Sanders could produce. If he’s forced to 
be more like C.J. Stroud, that could be difficult.  
Sanders has enough throwing talent and athletic ability to start in the NFL, but those are not the difference-making traits of his game. His 
mind for the game and willingness to work at it will have to be.

analysis:
**Jalen Sanders - Quarterback Summary**

**Strengths:**

* **Throwing Talent & Athleticism:** Possesses sufficient arm talent and athletic ability to play in the NFL.  He has a well-defined drop and stance.
* **Pocket Presence (with caveats):**  Will stand in the pocket against interior pressure to make throws, especially to the flat.


**Opportunities/Weaknesses:**

* **Decision-Making, Especially in the Red Zone:**  Takes unnecessary risks, particularly in the red zone (black zone). Needs to be more conservative and minimize risk early in games.
* **Game Management:** Requires significant improvement in game management skills. His leadership role in college may be contributing to poor decision-making that needs tempering in the NFL.
* **Pocket Mobility & Trusting His Eyes:** Lacks high-end mobility and relies too much on his legs instead of his eyes, potentially leading to injuries and poor decisions (like early-career Baker Mayfield and Russell Wilson). Needs to learn to throw the ball away earlier, especially on designed sprints.
* **Midfield Accuracy:** Struggles with manipulating defenders in the middle of the field, leading to uncertainty in projecting his ability to win there.

**NFL Player Comparisons:**

* **Early-Career Baker Mayfield & Russell Wilson:**  Sanders' reliance on his legs over his eyes poses a risk of mimicking their early-career struggles.  This is especially true if he is forced into a starting role before he is ready.
* **C.J. Stroud (as a potential negative comparison):** If forced into a situation requiring quick, decisive throws like Stroud, Sanders may struggle.


**Overall:** Sanders has the physical tools but needs significant development in decision-making, game management, and pocket presence to succeed in the NFL.  A gradual transition into a starting role, ideally behind a strong offensive line and rushing attack, would maximize his chances of success.

Sanders can make the quick one-step drop and throw to the opposite flat from under center. He has good spacing with three-step drops but 
the pacing must be quicker.  
His three-, five-, and seven-step drops are well-paced and finish with a balanced stance. He can manipulate opponents during his drops 
when he opens his torso to a side of the field.  
Sanders pivots efficiently into his stance off a read fake.  
Ball Security: Sanders holds the ball with both hands as he drops and stands in the pocket. When he accelerates to break the pocket, the 
ball drops to his thighs and he waves the ball around as he runs—I wish I could spin it as a series of pump fakes—but it would be like telling 
you the moon landing was faked. Pursuit has forced fumbles because of Sanders’ lapses with ball security.  
Sanders has been a part of multiple snaps in the red zone where he wasn’t ready or the center had the wrong snap count—both are 
Sanders’ responsibility as the leader of the unit.  
Play Fakes: Sanders follows through with the read exchange thoroughly. He has a thorough pitch fake to set up a sprint pass in the 
opposite direction. He’s quick and precise with his reverse fake after delivering the fly sweep.  
Pump Fakes: Sanders has a pump fake where he earns complete arm motion with the ball but the violence is minimal. It looks like he’s 
pawing at the air with the ball. He’ll also flash the ball with minimal movement.  
Release: Sanders delivers the ball with an efficient, over-the-shoulder motion that’s compact and with a high release point. There’s weight 
transfer from the back foot to the front.  
The midline of the back foot is aligned with the target. Sanders doesn’t get his front toe pointed on out-breaking routes as often as he 
should and

**Strengths:**

* **Dropbacks:**  Sanders demonstrates proficiency in various dropback depths (one, three, five, seven steps), maintaining balance and exhibiting good pacing in longer drops.  He effectively manipulates defensive positioning during his drops.
* **Play-action:** He executes play fakes convincingly, setting up subsequent plays (sprint passes, fly sweeps).
* **Release:**  His throwing motion is efficient, compact, with a high release point and proper weight transfer.

**Opportunities/Weaknesses:**

* **Ball Security:**  Sanders displays inconsistent ball security, especially when scrambling, leading to fumbles.  This needs significant improvement.
* **Pocket Awareness/Leadership:** He's shown instances of unpreparedness in the red zone, indicating potential issues with communication or leadership within the offensive unit.
* **Pump Fakes:** While he executes pump fakes, their effectiveness is questionable due to a lack of convincing movement; they appear weak and unconvincing.
* **Footwork on Throws:** He needs to improve his footwork, specifically pointing his front toe on out-breaking routes for better accuracy.
* **Three-Step Drop Pacing:** Needs to quicken his pacing on three-step drops.


**NFL Player Comparison:**  The provided text does not offer any NFL player comparisons.  A more comprehensive evaluation including game film and statistical data would be necessary to make accurate comparisons.

* **Tight Window Throws:**  Needs to improve throwing into tight windows requiring accurate ball placement over defenders.
* **Pocket Awareness & Decision Making:**  Tends to hold onto the ball too long when abandoning the pocket, leading to sacks.  He needs to improve his decision-making on when to throw the ball away.

However, based on his strengths and weaknesses, Sanders might be compared to quarterbacks who are strong in intermediate routes and zone reads but need to develop their deep ball accuracy and quick-decision making under pressure. * **Late-in-Play Decision Making:**  He's criticized for a tendency to make poor throws in the middle of the field and in the red zone, suggesting potential problems with his late-game decision making.
* **Handling Late Pressure:**  While effective at evading early pressure, the analysis doesn't explicitly address how he handles pressure that closes in later in the play.

**NFL Player Comparisons:**

Based on the provided information, a direct NFL comparison is difficult. However, his strengths suggest a potential comparison to mobile quarterbacks known for their accuracy under pressure and improvisational ability.  The analysis hints at a quarterback who might be similar to a less refined version of players like:

* **Russell Wilson (early career):**  Both exhibit exceptional pocket mobility and the ability to make plays outside of structure.  However, Sanders' potential weaknesses with late-game decisions and deep ball accuracy separates him from Wilson's prime.
* **Lamar Jackson (with caveats):** The scrambling ability and off-platform accuracy align. However, Jackson's arm strength and running ability are arguably superior, while the analysis suggests concerns with Sanders' decision-making that don't necessarily apply to Jackson.

It’s important to note that these comparisons are tentative and incomplete without a more thorough scouting report.  More data on his arm strength, deep ball accuracy, overall decision-making, and leadership traits would be necessary for a more accurate assessment and comparison.

multiple defenders in the area and a defender bearing down on Sanders during the release.

He has pinpoint accurate throws 25 yards to the boundary.  
Decision-Making: Sanders is prone to targeting intermediate routes breaking back to him at the boundary when there’s a 
defender squatting on the route over the top. Sanders does not understand the defender has the leverage advantage, especially 
when throwing from the far hash.  
Compounding the problem, Sanders takes the risk with these routes in his team’s red zone. Black-zone decision-making, especially 
early in contests, should be far more conservative and minimize risk.  
Sanders will throw the ball away if interior pressure reaches the pocket quickly or the pocket is so compressed that he can’t move 
away from the read that isn’t open. He must learn to throw the ball away earlier when on designed sprints. He lacks high-end 
mobility and he must trust his eyes more and his legs less.  
Sanders holds one side of the field to set up a throw to the opposite flat and will stand in against interior pressure to execute. I 
don’t see manipulation of defenders in the middle of the field.  
He places targets low and away from coverage that could otherwise cut off or hit the receiver.

buying time, but when he uses this move, he usually throws the ball away. He can buy time from one side of the field
analysis:
**Quarterback: Sanders**

**Strengths:**

* **Accuracy:**  Exhibits pinpoint accuracy on short, intermediate, and deep throws, even while on the move (both right and left) and off-platform.  He consistently places the ball low and away from coverage, minimizing interceptions.  His back-shoulder fade throws are particularly notable.
* **Pocket Presence (to a degree):** He's willing to stand in the pocket against interior pressure to make throws, showcasing some courage and resolve. He's effective at using stop-start movements to evade pressure and buy time.


**Opportunities for Improvement:**

* **Decision-Making:**  Prone to poor decisions, especially in the red zone, targeting intermediate routes with defenders in advantageous positions. He needs to improve his understanding of leverage and  be more conservative with his throws, particularly early in games.  He also needs to improve his ability to throw the ball away earlier when under pressure, especially on designed sprints.
* **Mobility:** While he can buy time, his mobility is not high-end. He relies too much on his legs and needs to trust his eyes more to make quicker, better decisions.  Lack of manipulation of defenders in the middle of the field limits his effectiveness.


**NFL Player Comparisons:**

Due to his accuracy, especially on the move and off-platform, while exhibiting some flaws in decision making, Sanders could be compared to a less mobile version of quarterbacks like **Russell Wilson (early in his career)**, or even a less polished **Josh Allen** in terms of needing refinement to his decision-making process.  His tendency to hold one side of the field to create throws to the opposite flat suggests a potential similarity to quarterbacks who rely heavily on play-action concepts to create opportunities. The comparison isn't perfect for any of these, however, due to the significant differences in overall mobility and decision-making consistency.

analysis:
The provided text analyzes a quarterback, referred to as "Sanders," focusing primarily on his mobility and arm talent, rather than offering a comprehensive evaluation.  There is no mention of leadership qualities or intangibles. Here's a summary:


**Sanders - Quarterback Analysis**

**Strengths:**

* **Mobility:** Sanders possesses impressive short-area quickness, allowing him to evade pressure and extend plays. He can effectively move in the pocket, buying time to throw and even utilizing his legs to gain yardage. His ability to move laterally is a significant asset.  He demonstrates the ability to throw accurately while on the move, both left and right.  He shows a strong arm, capable of completing long passes (up to 50 yards) with catchable accuracy, even under pressure.  He can effectively throw to the opposite boundary.

**Opportunities/Weaknesses:**

* **Decision-Making:** Sanders exhibits inconsistency in his decision-making, particularly in the red zone, where he has made costly mistakes including interceptions. His ability to read defenses, especially safety rotations, needs improvement, as evidenced by several missed opportunities and poor leverage reads.  Sometimes he throws the ball away when retreating, potentially indicating a lack of confidence in making a play under pressure.
* **Pocket Presence:** While mobile, his restart quickness after changing direction is not a notable strength, and he can be reckless in the pocket at times.  
* **Durability:** No significant injuries are reported, a positive aspect of his profile.


**NFL Player Comparisons:**

The text explicitly compares Sanders to a "slow Kyler Murray," highlighting his mobility but acknowledging a difference in speed.  The reference to Mayfield and Smith suggests a potential for similar career trajectories (perhaps inconsistent performance or late-round draft status followed by inconsistent NFL success).  This comparison doesn't necessarily indicate a high ceiling but implies the potential for a middling NFL career with some level of success in specific areas.


**Overall:**

Sanders presents a fascinating but incomplete prospect.  His athleticism and arm talent are considerable strengths, but his decision-making and consistency need significant improvement. His NFL success will largely hinge on his ability to refine his pocket awareness and reduce risky plays. His draft stock remains uncertain, and his value largely depends on team fit and draft capital.
